TITLE.XREF: VETERANS' AFFAIRS LEGISLATION AMENDMENT (1996‐97 BUDGET AND OTHER MEASURES) BILL 1997

PROCTEXT.PARA: Consideration resumed from 26 June 1997.

TALK.START.PARA: —The committee is considering the Veterans' Affairs Legislation Amendment (1996‐97 Budget and Other Measures) Bill 1997 and amendments 2, 4 and 5 moved by Senator Neal for the opposition.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Neal, Sen Belinda

TALK.START.PARA: —The opposition opposes schedule 5 in the following terms:

SPEECH.PARA: (6) Schedule 5, page 21 (line 2) to page 24 (line 11), TO BE OPPOSED .

Opposition amendment No. 6 seeks to delete the provision relating to the deeming of superannuation for those between the ages of 55 and 60. In fact, you will see that opposition amendment No. 6 and the Democrat amendment are one and the same. So, by moving item 6 in our amendments we are, in fact, moving the Democrat amendment No. 1 as well.

TALK.START.PARA: —Yes, that's right.
—Can we clarify whether you are opposing schedule 5. Is that correct?

—Opposition amendment No. 6 opposes schedule 5. Essentially, the effect of our amendment would be to provide that the superannuation of veterans between the age of 55 and retirement age in particular would not be taken into account in determining their access to benefits. The effect of removal of the deeming for veterans in budgetary terms is relatively small. We believe that, in particular, veterans are a class of persons who should not be treated harshly and that we have particular responsibilities to them. As I have stated previously and as the opposition has stated very clearly, we are opposed on principle to deeming on the basis of superannuation. We strenuously oppose measures which adversely affect veterans, as schedule 5 of the Veterans' Affairs Legislation Amendment (1996‐97 Budget and Other Measures) Bill 1997 does.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Woodley, Sen John

TALK.START.PARA: —Schedule 5 of the veterans' affairs bill seeks to mirror a change made to the Social Security Act late last year. That change was to include the value of superannuation assets in the social security means test and the schedule makes a similar change to the veterans' affairs act. The Australian Democrats opposed this move late last year and will be opposing it again today. We do so on the following grounds.

SPEECH.PARA: The first one is to perhaps reply to the government's arguments, which I have listened to carefully—that is, savings should not be treated differently. But the whole point of superannuation is that there was cross-party agreement when the superannuation system was set up that in fact it would be treated differently. That was the whole point of the exercise. It is not only me who says that but in fact many people on the Liberal side who, of course, because of party discipline, are unable to vote the way they feel.

TALK.START.PARA: —Not at all.
—Minister, they have rung me. They have rung me to tell me so.
—They are not ringing me, my friend.
—Obviously they would not ring you, Minister, because you are not going to listen to them. That is why they are desperately ringing other people.
—It's a party decision.

—Of course it is. That is exactly what I am saying. It is a party decision, so they are unable to do anything about their frustration and apprehension about this bill. I am saying to you, Minister, that I do not accept one of your fundamental arguments—that is, somehow or other savings are the same. Deliberately and on a multiparty basis for at least four years—and this is what the electorate understands—we have been working on the assumption that superannuation would be treated differently from other savings. That is the fundamental point in this whole argument. So I reject the government's argument on that basis.

SPEECH.PARA: On some of the other grounds, we believe that superannuation assets should be exempt to ensure that the nest eggs of many people who have worked hard to provide for their retirement are protected. In other words, it is pointless telling people over a long period of time, `This is what you should do,' and, when they finally get to the stage where they need to absolutely ensure that those nest eggs are protected so they can look after themselves in retirement, then change the rules and say, `No, we're going to make you cut into that nest egg so that you'll no longer be able to do what you thought the government was telling you to do for many years.'

Secondly, we believe that it is unfair for the government to encourage people into superannuation through tax breaks and the like and then clearly penalise those people for having followed that encouragement. This is the problem. I do not think the government understands what it does to people when it changes the rules after a long period of time when they have been doing what they thought the government was telling them to do. It changes the rules and leaves them stranded.

This whole move should be opposed because it threatens public confidence and support for Australia's superannuation system, confidence and support on which our super system relies. I can tell you that the people out there, not the people who are trying to rort the system—there are certainly some of those—but the vast majority of people, are really starting to lose confidence in the whole business of retirement because they are unable to know just what they should do when governments continually change the rules. Without that kind of public confidence, it will be impossible to encourage people to save for their own retirement because they will say, `What's the point? We start off on one basis and then, before we know it, the rules are changed and we're left stranded.'

BREAK.PARA: Let us not forget that the people who will be affected by this change are those who have tried their hardest to provide for themselves in retirement and tried to lessen the load on our aged pension system. Over the past few weeks in the Senate, I have tabled a petition. When I wrote this speech a couple of weeks ago, there were 5,000 signatures. Since then, I have received another 1,500, so I have crossed it out and it is now 6,500 signatures from people calling on the government to repeal the social security legislation on this issue. I will be seeking to do just that shortly but, at this stage, I indicate that the Democrats will be supporting the opposition's amendments—that is, we will be opposing schedule 5 in its entirety.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine, Sen Brian

TALK.START.PARA: —I am not going to go over the debate that has taken place on this veterans' affairs bill because of the time. Schedule 5, which we are dealing with, does remove the exemptions from income and assets tests that apply to the superannuation and rollover funds assets of certain service pensioners and income support supplement recipients, as is explained in the explanatory memorandum. For the reasons that I gave yesterday, I am opposing this particular clause. The government now has a number of options open to it to see and realise that there is a great deal of feeling amongst the community about how this is going to operate so far as the ones who are affected are concerned.

SPEECH.PARA: As has been indicated, there are a huge number of people for whom this will be a great problem because they will have planned otherwise, on the basis of existing legislation. Persons between the ages of 55 and 65 who have lost their jobs are going to be affected by this. If their superannuation happens to be above the limits that are set in this particular legislation, they will be told that they have to dip into it.

I remember the debate of last December. I also remember the letter from the Minister for Social Security (Senator Newman), or presumably from the department, and the note that I had sent around to people who raised this matter. The document put out by the Minister for Social Security and the Minister for Veterans' Affairs (Mr Scott) on 7 November entitled `Information on the removal of the superannuation social security means test exemption for people aged between 55 and age pension age' contains figures which, whilst implying to be pertaining to 55‐ to 64‐year‐olds—I got a very strong response in respect of this—are relevant to the 65‐plus‐year‐olds only.

I have had a look at that document. I can see in hindsight that, if you are fully aware of what the issues are and go through the arguments, strictly speaking the document is accurate. I will read from a letter that I received from a person who was personally interested in this matter. The person said:

It is fact that (conveniently) the income and assets tests tables 1 and 2 (on pages 3 and 4) are the figures for aged pensioners (stuck in the middle of a document expressly referring to 55‐ to 64‐year‐olds) and the mistake (perhaps deliberate) gives the false impression that aged pensioners and 55‐ to 64‐year‐olds are to be treated to identical assets test rules.

This person, who quite clearly has a deep and abiding interest in the matter, and even with his expertise in the area, felt that the statement that was issued could lead to confusion. One might say that politicians should not be confused; unfortunately, we do get confused from time to time. I am not suggesting that, in respect of anything I have asked the minister, she has not been open, honest and fulsome in her response.

The sad part is that we are debating this matter. We are poisoning the debate over a piece of legislation on which the minister should be congratulated and the Minister for Veterans' Affairs should be congratulated. Let me make it perfectly clear: the overwhelming provisions in this legislation are thoroughly beneficial to veterans. It is this provision, because of the time constraints, that we are focusing on at the present. I will be voting against the whole of schedule 5.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Newman, Sen Jocelyn
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: Social Security; Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women

TALKER.NAME: Senator NEWMAN
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Social Security and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women)

TALK.START.PARA: —I must say that I am very disappointed with the attitude that has been taken by the committee today to schedule 5 of the veterans' affairs bill. I do not know where I should start. I will respond to Senator Woodley first and then move on to Senator Harradine.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Woodley, you are failing to acknowledge that superannuation is already given preferential treatment through the tax system. There is across‐party lines agreement that there should be preferential treatment for this, or that it should be treated differently—and it is treated differently in the tax system. Why would the Democrats want to continue to give preferential treatment also in the social security and veterans area?

This special treatment, as I have said before, has been available to these people since only 1993. People, especially veterans, made their investment decisions a number of years ago. So, in fact, they have not been misled. They had a period of misguided intervention by the previous government. I will give it the benefit of the doubt and believe it was trying to do the right thing by people.

At the time that superannuation was exempted from the means test, it was believed that it would be just a modest cost to revenue. But because the financial planners had in fact found this a great opportunity to change people's investment patterns, it had become something of a rort, and, if we had not closed it in December, it would have been an enormous drain on revenue.

I urge you to think very carefully before you try any measures to undo what already has been done. It is of great concern to the government. I am advised that something like $300 million over four years would be lost if the social security legislation was not maintained in the form it was passed by the Senate last December. I also emphasise that people can access their superannuation savings from age 55. That is the law; they can access it now. Why treat it as though it is inaccessible? It is available.

Senator Harradine was talking about people losing their jobs. At this age some people are choosing to take voluntary redundancy and some people—keen fishermen amongst them—think that the idea of going fishing on and off for the last five years or so of what might be their working lives is an attractive proposition, if they can leave their superannuation tucked away safely and get the taxpayer to give them income support for those few years. How rational or fair is it to ask the taxpayers to be funding voluntary retirement? Superannuation is intended to provide that. If people are over the age of 55 and have the means, through superannuation, to support themselves, to the extent they are able, surely that is fair to all.

I think there is a lot of feeling from taxpayers that the revenue should be protected and that income support should be applied according to people's means, as it always has been in the Social Security Act. I would call the three years from 1993 an aberration, and a most unfortunate one, because it did open up the revenue to serious impacts. We already demonstrated in the debate last December that it was gathering momentum until that legislation was passed. I urge the Senate to think very carefully before they take a different tack now.

Senator Harradine, I had a very great respect for your former adviser, Terry Dwyer, who was a man of infinite capacity and great experience. I think he came out of the Treasury, from memory. You were very well served by him. I think my department, but certainly my office and myself, had long discussions with him about this measure and others. I always found him very able to get on top of the detail in these areas. As I said to you a day or so ago, he was very helpful on occasions on matters that needed detailed attention. He well understood these measures. I understood that you understood them, and certainly that the document that you referred to just now was talked through with my officers and with Mr Dwyer. There was no attempt to deceive anybody. We understood that the details of that document were well understood.

One of the things you must acknowledge is that most of the people affected by last year's amendments to the Social Security Act are pensioners. Therefore, the table you were referring to about pensioners was very relevant to this whole debate. Most people are pensioners. I have some figures here in relation to the social security legislation. Only 18,400 allowees are estimated to be affected by that measure in 1997-98 compared to around 48,600 pensioners. Of those allowees, only 4,300 are actually on activity tested allowances. In other words, the rest are retired—they are not looking for work and they are not being required to look for work. So I am afraid that there are still obviously some severe misapprehensions around as to who is affected by that measure in social security for which we are now debating a comparable measure for veterans' affairs.

It is not true that this is not a fair measure. This is a particularly fair measure. You have to recognise that, until relatively recently, superannuation has not been something that most people have; it is just in recent years that people have started to accumulate superannuation. But they have other forms of savings: they have had money in the bank, they have had shares, they have had term deposits and they have had money in their small business, as I said to you yesterday. All those forms of savings have been and still are means tested.

For just over three years superannuation was not means tested. We are putting it back so that all forms of savings are treated in the social security and veterans' affairs legislation in a comparable way—fair to people who have savings, regardless of what form they take. Over time, of course, more and more Australians will have more and more of their retirement savings in the form of superannuation. We encourage that. We are happy and delighted for that to happen. That is why there is tax assistance for it, which there is not for most of the other forms of savings.

I think you have to give careful thought as to why we should be giving preference in the social security and the veterans' affairs legislation for particular forms of savings. It is no more virtuous than any other. Why should it be accorded different and special treatment?

As I said, veterans who are already over 55 made their investment decisions many years ago. It only affects people who are below pension age and over 55 and who have received income support payments for at least 39 weeks since reaching 55. Far and away, the majority of them are already retired.

BREAK.PARA: Of particular interest to the committee is that the pension age for a veteran with qualifying service is five years earlier than others in the community. For a male veteran, the pension age is 60 and for a female veteran, the pension age is currently 55.5 years. To be paid a service pension before pension age, a veteran would be permanently incapacitated for work. As such, the veteran would be eligible for payment of superannuation. They would already receive the more generous assets and income test levels in most circumstances.

I did emphasise in the second reading debate yesterday that exemptions from the new rules will be considered on a case by case basis where people aged between 55 and pension age are unable to access superannuation. There is not a great number of those. For example, if a partner of a service pensioner is unable to access their super at 55, the Minister for Veterans' Affairs can exempt the superannuation from the extended deeming provisions, just as I can in the social security legislation.

The means test free areas will protect people with modest amounts of superannuation and/or rollover savings; that is, total financial investments less than $50,000 for a single pensioner or $90,000 for a couple. The taxpayer should not be required to supplement the people who have access to their superannuation but who choose not to put their superannuation to its intended use, and that is what this measure is about.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine, Sen Brian

TALK.START.PARA: —I will be seeking leave of the Senate to table a letter addressed to me by Mr A.R. Oakes of Morphettville in South Australia. I have shown the document to the minister's advisers. Perhaps we could leave it on hold until the minister has seen it.

SPEECH.PARA: I must say that I have taken a good deal of interest in this matter and am very clear in my mind as to what I ought to do. I acknowledge that I have been served very well by Dr Dwyer, my adviser, as I have been served extremely well by all of my advisers over the last 22 years. I do not think it is appropriate to say anything more. The buck stops with me, and I intend to vote against this schedule.

BREAK.PARA: It might be said that this is discriminating in favour of veterans. There will be a lessening of that discrimination if and when Senator Woodley's next amendment is adopted. Already, as the minister has pointed out, to some extent there is discrimination in favour of veterans when it comes to retiring age. That has been the case for quite a considerable number of years. I seek leave to table the document.
Leave granted.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: The TEMPORARY CHAIRMAN

TALK.START.PARA: —The question is that schedule 5 stand as printed.

SPEECH.PARA: Question resolved in the negative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Neal, Sen Belinda

TALK.START.PARA: —I would just like to indicate at this stage that the opposition will not be proceeding with its amendments 2, 3, 4 and 5.

SPEECH.PARA: Amendments—by leave—withdrawn.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Woodley, Sen John

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (2) Page 49 (after line 5), at the end of the bill, add:

PARA.EMPHASIS: Schedule 10—Amendments of the Social Security Legislation Amendment (Further Budget and Other Measures) Act 1996 relating to the means test exemption for superannuation assets in certain cases

SPEECH.PARA: Repeal the Schedule.
Repeal the Schedule.

My next amendment really is a logical progression from what we have just done, and that is to attach a schedule which will restore in the social security legislation the same provision that we have just dealt with in the veterans' affairs legislation. Schedule 5 of this bill was knocked off because the Australian Democrats were opposed to inclusion of superannuation assets in Social Security and Veterans' Affairs income and assets test.

Since the social security legislation was passed last year I have been contacted by hundreds of people whose retirement plans have been thrown into chaos by this legislation. I have collected, as I said before, the signatures of now over 6,500 people calling on the government to repeal this legislation, and more petitions are coming into my office every day.

In the light of this very strong community response and also because of what I have put on the record previously, which I really do believe in, it is appropriate for the Senate to reconsider its position on this issue as well. The figures I have show that this affects not only people with large amounts of superannuation. The deeming rules mean that anyone with as little as $37,000 in superannuation will have their allowance reduced. So what I am seeking to do now is a logical progression from the decision we have just taken, and that is to restore the same provision in the social security legislation.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Neal, Sen Belinda

TALK.START.PARA: —The opposition will be supporting Australian Democrat amendment No. 2. As senators might recall, in debate on the social security legislation in December last year this was, in essence, the same amendment put by the opposition in that case. We believe that, in general, a means test should be applied to social security payments. But we clearly have the view that superannuation is not an asset in the sense of all other assets. There has been an agreement between the general population and all parties, including the government, that superannuation is a special asset and it is to be retained until retirement age to ensure particularly individual security of income and to prevent the community from having to contribute to people's retirement income.

SPEECH.PARA: Clearly the inclusion of deeming provisions that apply to superannuation and the payment of social security would be a breach of this agreement. As a result, we are and have been opposed to this provision and we will be supporting the Democrats' amendment.

TALK.START.PARA: —First of all, I acknowledge what the minister did last night—that was, to put before the Senate the exemptions that should apply in respect of superannuants with superannuation assets and exemptions that should apply for those who are over 55. They are called `customers' in the document. I acknowledge the work that was done with regard to that particular matter. However, having given this matter considerable thought, I have decided, for the reasons I previously expressed, to support the amendment that is now before the chamber.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Newman, Sen Jocelyn
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: Social Security; Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women

TALKER.NAME: Senator NEWMAN
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Social Security and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women)

TALK.START.PARA: —This amendment effectively was being debated during the consideration of the previous amendment. I am very concerned that the Senate is trying to turn around, using the peg of a veterans bill—after all, we do usually have bipartisan support on veterans legislation—a bill that the veterans have being waiting on for a long time to get through the legislative logjam. This bill is of particular importance to Vietnam veterans. For the Senate to artificially use that bill as a peg with which to hang a quite different agenda in relation to superannuation means testing for all other people, not particularly veterans, is a terrible state of affairs.

SPEECH.PARA: Can I make clear once again that the advice of my department is that the loss of revenue in the first year will be something like $90 million and it will be approaching $300 million over four years. The Senate has to think very carefully about how it is going to explain that to the Australian taxpayer. Senator Woodley is very keen to tell us that he has people signing a petition on this matter. Senator, you could get an even bigger petition if you went around asking people whether they would like income tax abolished. You should go and try that one. I am not impressed by your petition. I am impressed by the people who take the trouble to write to the minister or the department.

My colleagues in my party are not lobbying me to do something about this measure. They have found that it is fair, and that is why they are not lobbying me. You suggest that somehow they are bound by party solidarity and that they would not even come and talk to their minister, their colleague. You are wrong. That is not the way we run our party. I am very approachable. I meet with my backbench committee weekly. The party room is always ready to cross‐examine ministers thoroughly. I can assure you that your claims about my colleagues are untrue.

BREAK.PARA: In addition, you are holding up a beneficial measure for veterans. Everybody has acknowledged that this rehabilitation scheme is long overdue to prevent veterans becoming welfare dependent for all their lives. The Vietnam Veterans Association in particular has seen that this is a way to help their people. This attempt to wind back a lawful decision of the Senate made only on 13 December last year is absolutely disgraceful. I can hardly find the words sufficient to express my disgust at what you are attempting.

You, and Senator Harradine in particular, may well have been seen as a convenient post to lobby by those people who have a vested interest in this. I can assure Senator Harradine that I understand the pressure he is under, not just on this legislation but also on a large number of the bills that come before the parliament. I feel very sorry for him, because of the position he is in. He has this responsibility and has the pressure of the lobbyists of Australia continually beating on his door.

But I say to him, as I say to the other parties, that the people that yell loudest are not the people you should be concerned about now. There is a great deal of self-interest there. What you are doing by trying to wind back the measure we passed last December is protecting millionaires. The battlers are already protected by what we have put in place and by the exemptions I have given people who cannot access their superannuation.

So you should be under no misapprehension whatsoever about what you are doing. You are protecting the millionaires of Australia who have extraordinary amounts of superannuation tucked away in hollow logs. In 1993 rich people were able to move assets into roll-over funds and superannuation—very convenient. This is why there are books in this country telling people how to be millionaires and still get welfare benefits, still be entitled to the money that battlers are paying for social security income support for people who are well able to support themselves.

It is utterly disgraceful that you would contemplate doing that. It is absolutely disgraceful. The government rejects this amendment out of hand. We will not accept it and we will make it very clear to the nation just who is responsible for delaying the veterans entitlements and putting $300 million of revenue at risk.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Neal, Sen Belinda

TALK.START.PARA: —There are two matters I wish to respond to that have been raised by the minister. The first is her allegation of the delay involved in the consideration of this particular piece of legislation. I wish to emphasise again, as I did at the beginning of the second reading stage, that we are in support of the majority of this bill relating to the rehabilitation and simplification of payments to veterans. But I must remind the minister that the bills that are dealt with by this chamber are determined by the government. If there has been delay in putting forward this particularly beneficial piece of legislation, then the responsibility stops with you, Minister, and the other members of your government, because you determine the priority.

SPEECH.PARA: In relation to the benefits to be obtained from this bill, I must say that I find it somewhat remarkable that you are essentially prepared to hold hostage a scheme such as this in order to get your own way in an area where the Senate has clearly expressed its view. I would like to indicate that at the appropriate time, if you proceed with your threat and try to hold back this bill, we will either split the bill or move the positive aspects of the bill in our name in order to avoid the callous action that you intend to visit on veterans.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine, Sen Brian

TALK.START.PARA: —I was not going to say anything more, but I think the minister's outburst has been intemperate, to say the least. To suggest that somehow or another I am bowing to the lobbyists and their self-interest, I find insulting. I have a situation in my office where I largely deal at arm's length with lobbyists. I have to say that I am aware of people who are, and will be, seriously affected by the measures that were adopted last year. This gives us an opportunity to redress that position. I am glad to see Senator Sherry in the chamber, because I know one or two of the people who had written to Senator Sherry quite well.
—They are not millionaires.

—Precisely. They are not millionaires—you can say that again. I think it is ludicrous for the minister to say that what we are doing is in the interests of millionaires. If she and her department are not monitoring the situation, it would be their fault, because we are not talking about lifting the amounts above that which would be an even playing field. I give you the example that is in the letter that I have tabled. I do not know this person—that is obvious—and I suggest you read the letter.

SPEECH.PARA: I remind the Senate that I asked Senator Sherry in December last year:
. . . why should someone with a house, plus $180,000, plus $250,000 in superannuation be regarded as eligible for welfare?

I might have answered somewhat differently from the response that Senator Sherry gave, but I thought Senator Sherry's response was quite a good one too. I now want to quote the following comments from my correspondent:

That may be a valid question where you cite the case of someone with $430,000 in monetary assets. But regarding equity, why should someone with a house, who is 65 and has elected to retire with $250,000 in superannuation, be regarded as eligible for welfare, and yet someone who is 55 to 64 and loses their job, also with $250,000 in superannuation assets, is not eligible for welfare unless their total assets, excluding house, are less than $176,000? Is this fair?
The quote continues:

I am assuming that the retirees referred to in the above paragraph are both married; therefore, the iniquitous anomaly is because a 65‐year‐old couple are allowed assets of $370,500 in order to be considered for eligibility for pension payments. As an example of the unfairness of the new rules, the following assumes a home owner couple with $30,000 in possessions and $250,000 in superannuation savings . . .

Not a millionaire, Minister—$30,000 in possessions and $250,000 built up over a lifetime. The 65‐year‐old plus gets a DSS payment of $5,064 and the person of 55 to 64 who has lost their job gets zero—nothing.

Then it goes on to what interest is accrued each year and the total received. Can that couple live on $15,000 a year? I do not know how people manage. The bottom line is that the person who has lost the job, that couple, is discriminated against to the tune of $192 a fortnight. We are not talking about millionaires. We are talking about, I believe, equity and fairness. I am not going over the subject again. I have thought about this deeply and I do believe that, in a period of unemployment—it is different from last December; things are worse at the moment—you have to have regard for these people that are losing their jobs. They are not millionaires.

You have to have regard for them, when they are losing jobs at age 55 to 64, because they find it very difficult to get back into the paid work force. Indeed, as I said yesterday, I believe that rather than doing this sort of negative thing, the government ought to be encouraging persons to retire early. Give them some incentive to retire earlier so as to relieve those who desire to do so and to relieve pressure on the work force. But no, the government is going the other way around. It is giving bonuses to those who are fortunate to be able to choose to work till they are 70 years of age.

TALKER.NAME: Senator SHERRY
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Opposition in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —Very briefly, I want to join with my Tasmanian Senate colleague Senator Harradine in expressing my concern at the outrageous allegations that Senator Newman has made about millionaires being affected by this measure.
—Doug Krushka is not a millionaire.

—Exactly. Mr Krushka is not a millionaire. He is on the north-west coast. I do not want to disclose the extent of his superannuation assets, but it is much less than $½ million let alone $1 million. Senator Newman, you show just how much out of touch you are. Just reflecting on Mr Krushka, I have had conversations with his financial adviser, Mr Burn. He represents 200 people in Tasmania who are affected by this deeming provision. Not one of them is a millionaire; not one of them would have $½ million.
—There aren't too many millionaires in Tasmania.
—Exactly, Senator Newman, there are not too many millionaires in Tasmania, so how could you come in here and claim that this measure is allowing millionaires to get off? You grossly exaggerate.
—It is; it really is.
—Well, last year, Senator Newman, we presented you with a solution to this. We presented you with a cap of $250,000.
—That was stupid.

—It was not stupid, Senator Newman. If you were concerned about millionaires, you would have supported us last year in inserting the cap of $250,000. Now, $250,000 sounds like a lot of money, but what does it mean in reality if converted to a pension? What it means, at today's interest rates, is that if you go and purchase with your $250,000 an annuity for life you will get approximately $15,000 to $17,000 a year. That is what that converts into. Last year, Labor thought that seemed to be a reasonable figure to establish a cut‐off point at.

BREAK.PARA: I would like to assure the Senate—and to agree with Senator Harradine and Senator Woodley—that Labor has taken a consistent position, for the reasons we have outlined, that the many tens of thousands of people to be affected by this draconian measure, this vicious measure, workers who have built up over a long period, voluntarily in many cases, a reasonable superannuation asset to live on when they retire, have had the goalposts changed.

That is grossly unfair and grossly inequitable. The document read as follows—
Introduction
The Tax Laws Amendment Bill No 1 is an omnibus Bill of some ten mostly unrelated changes, to the Income Tax Assessment Act.

In what is becoming a hall mark of this Government, any time they engage in amendment to the Tax Act it is a case of shove as many amendments or additions as is possible into the one omnibus bill and hope that the Senate doesn't disagree whether any aspect of those separate changes so that the Bill can pass.

As my colleague Mr Latham said in the House, grouping so many different changes together is `folly' and the Government should be aware that the Opposition is wary of this piecemeal approach to tax reform that the Government is engaging in.
This being said the Opposition will be supporting most aspects of the Bill with reservations that are outlined in the second reading amendment to the Bill that Senators should now have before them.
I would now like to comment those concerns.
Trading Ships Depreciation
Firstly, the Opposition is opposed to the Governments decision to bring forward the end of accelerated depreciation available on trading ships from the year 2002 to 1997.
This proposal which is contingent upon the disastrous decision to terminate the ships capital grants provisions will massively increase the costs facing Australian shippers.
For Australia to actively increase the costs of international shipping is ludicrous policy when it acts against our long term interests as a major trading nation.
Labor opposed the premature ending of the capital grants scheme and we similarly oppose the restriction of accelerated depreciation contained in this bill.

When coupled with the Governments original intention to end the ship building bounty at the end of this year, we have clear demonstration of the Governments total disregard for the Australian ship building industry and the devastation the Governments policies would have had on the industry.

While Australia's international competitors in the ship building enjoy far more significant government support than Australian ship builders, this Government is intent on making it as hard as possible for both investment and expansion of Australia's industry to continue.
Why is this Government against Australia's ship building industry ?
Why is the Government so intent on ensuring that Australia's ship builders ability to compete internationally against subsided international ship builders is destroyed ?

May be the Minister would like to answer those questions and explain to Australian ship builders and in particular workers in that industry why his Government is so intent on seeing them out of a job.
This being said the Opposition will be voting against the proposal as contained in schedule 1, part 1 of the Bill.
Employee Share Ownership Schemes
I would now like to turn to the issue of employee share schemes.
The Government proposal will see the invitation threshold for employee share schemes reduced from 75% of `employees' to 66% of `permanent employees'.

This measure therefore in effect contains two changes in one. Firstly the reduction in the number of employees who can participate from 75% to 66%, and secondly a change in eligible employees from `employees' to `permanent employees'.
The Opposition will therefore be opposing the change in the threshold, we see no logic or reason why there should be a reduction in the eligibility threshold.
We are also surprised that the Government would introduce such an amendment.
If anything I would have thought this Government would want to encourage employee share ownership and in particular encourage investment by Australian workers in Australian companies.
I note the comments by Senator Short the former Assistant Treasurer and avid share market investor as we all know.
He said in this place on the 13 February:

I am very proud to hold shares in several major Australian companies. Australia is crying out for productive investment. Shares are a critically important vehicle for such investment, and I am proud to be playing at least a small part.
Why then is the Government trying to restrict Australian workers from share ownership ?

The former Assistant Treasurer is an avid supporter of share ownership, as we all know, so why is the Government trying to deny Australian workers their opportunity to become shareholders, or is this only a privilege the
Government believes belongs to the top end of town, which it is increasingly becoming a captive of.

The other part of this change would appear technical in nature but none the less the Opposition would appreciate an explanation of why there is need to change from `employees' to `permanent employees' as the only ones who will be eligible to participate in the employee ownership scheme.

The opposition would appreciate if the Minister could explain what the difference is. why is their a need for this change ? And what is the definition of permanent employee for the purposes of this section.

The other major change contained in this section increases the amount by which an employee who acquires shares under an employee ownership scheme to claim an exemption from tax. This amount has increased from $500 to $1000, and applies to the discount received on the purchase of the shares.
Similarly, it allows employers to claim a tax deduction of up to $1000 on the discount provided.

The Opposition has no objection to this proposal, but does find it strange that at the same time the Government is reducing both the eligibility threshold and the category of employee who is eligible to take part in an employee share ownership scheme, it simultaneously increases the tax concession from $500 to $1000.
In light of this, as previously stated the Opposition opposes the reduction in the eligibility threshold and will be moving a amendment to this effect.
The Opposition will not be opposing the increase in the tax concession amount from $500 to $1000.
CGT Small Business Rollover Relief
The last issue I wish to speak on is that of the small business CGT rollover relief.

Before I start the substance of my comments I would like to congratulate the Government on keeping at least one promise amongst the hundreds they have broken by introducing the CGT rollover relief for small business.
The CGT rollover relief as contained in the provisions of Schedule 5 of this Bill are really the central focus of this Bill.
This measure coupled with the announcement that roll over relief would be extended to the sale of shares in a business amounts to a $315m in forgone revenue in a full year.
This is not an insignificant amount of money and given that over a 4 year period it amounts to over $1 billion.

The Opposition believes the Australian community deserve something in return for this loss of revenue considering it could be put to a host of other policy initiatives, such as labour market programs, legal aid, education funding and the reinstatement of the Commonwealth dental health scheme, just to name a few.

At a minimum and in essence, as a quid pro quo for Australian taxpayers essentially handing back to small business over a billion dollars in foregone revenue, small business should be required to ensure a net increase in employment when such rollover relief is claimed.
To this end the Opposition has announced amendments to this Bill to achieve that outcome.
Our amendments will see rollover relief become a reward to those small businesses that have increased employment.
Small business will have to satisfy one of two tests in order to claim the small business rollover relief.

The first test will be that a small business will have to have increased the average number of full time employees by at least 10% during the twelve month period following the acquisition of a new business relative to the 12 month period of the business that has been sold.
The second test under our proposal will allow rollover relief to be claimed in instances where the business has increased its payroll by at least 10% on the same basis as I have just outlined.
We in the Opposition believe these amendments to be fair and reasonable.
Under the Governments proposal as it currently stands small business stands to gain over one $1 billion in tax relief and there is no commitment to provide one new job, NOT ONE.

Furthermore these amendments will give credence to the Prime Ministers rhetoric of using small business as the engine room of economic growth and thus employment growth. If the PM and the Government are committed to employment growth then they will embrace these amendments and support them.

Given that the government is about to fuel that engine room with over $1 billion in tax relief, then surely employment generation should be the focus, and it is the Governments duty to ensure that job creation is the focus of this very generous tax relief.
The Prime Minister and the Treasurer have said that any tax reform proposal should have to pass three tests one of which is, and I quote `It must generate more employment.'
The transfer of over $1 billion from the public sector to the private sector is by the Oppositions reckoning a major tax reform proposal.

If the Prime Minister and Treasurer are serious, then the Government will support these amendments. If they do not to support them, then the Prime Ministers statement was nothing more than hollow rhetoric and his commitment to Australia's unemployed will be shown to be a cruel hoax and this provision of the Bill nothing more than an expensive exercise in pork barrelling in order to try and shore up its crumbling support in the small business community.

As my colleague in the other place Mr Latham essentially stated, whenever the business sector enjoys benefits from the public sector, there is a need for them to ensure a socially responsible outcome, these amendments ensure that outcome.

Such an outcome we in the Opposition believe is achieved by these amendments which ensure the business sector has to be committed to increasing net employment if they are going to receive over $1 billion in taxpayer funds.
The reality is there is always a large cost to the public sector in any form of business tax relief. The CGT rollover relief is certainly a large cost.
This cost represents an opportunity cost to the public sector and a very large one at that.

As the Prime Minister has made much of the need for the unemployed to accept a social responsibility when in receipt of the dole, through his announced work for the dole scheme, this same principle can apply to the small business sector that is in receipt of government assistance through $1 billion in tax relief.
They too have a social responsibility to put something back into the Australian community. Providing jobs for our young people in particular is but a small request for over $1 billion in tax relief.

The notion of reciprocal responsibilities should not be the exclusive preserve of the social welfare sector, which is what the Prime Ministers work for the dole scheme attempts to entrench in the public mind.

Why shouldn't the concept of business assistance through the CGT roll over relief amounting to over $1 billion over four years also carry the reciprocal responsibility of job creation as our amendments propose ?
This is the challenge for both the small business sector and in particular the Government.
Threat to the tax base
Under this bill as it currently stands we believe the Government is just adding to the number of threats our tax base already faces.
The Crisis Couriers case and its implications is but one example of the constant attacks being made on the integrity of the tax base.
It is notable that in the face of such threats this Government is prepared to do nothing, accept mouth platitudes about the need to stamp out rorting by the rich.

But when the previous Labor Govt identified up to $800m in revenue as being at risk due to high wealth individuals using complex trust tax arrangements, this Govt when in Opposition scoffed at the suggestion.
And why wouldn't they, because they would hardly want to upset their rich rorting Liberal mates.

Its the `Bottom of the Harbour' all over again being fed and encouraged by this Government's complacency and lack of commitment to stamp out tax rorting. This should come as no surprise though, given that at the time of the `Bottom of the Harbour schemes' who was the Treasurer in charge at the time, doing nothing, no one less than the present Prime Minister Mr Howard. He did nothing then and he continues to do nothing now, because its not in the interests of the Liberal party to upset their Liberal mates.

When you put the Governments complacency together with advances in such things as information technology and the explosion in electronic commerce it should be evident to the Govt that now more than ever they need to be increasingly vigilance to ensure that the structural integrity of the tax base is maintained.

I have no doubt that electronic commerce poses one of the biggest threats of our time to the revenue base of national Governments around the world, and it therefore causes me concern when measures such as the one before us have the very real possibility of eroding the integrity of the tax base, at a time when Governments need to prevent such erosion.

I would be interested to hear the Governments opinion on this matter and whether they believe in the absence of these amendments which put the rollover relief to towards a positive measure in the form of employment generation, will their bill as it stands open up the possibility of widespread rorting, not by small business but by the creative accountants and lawyers who I am sure are champing at the bit to see what sort of schemes and arrangements they can devise in order to circumvent the actual intent of the legislation. r

It also concerns the Opposition that in the absence of a reciprocal obligation on the part of business to provide employment through the use of the tax relief as is the intention of the Oppositions amendments, the Government is giving a tax break to some who are already independently wealthy.
In particular I make reference to an answer given by the Assistant Treasurer to a question on notice I posed to him on the 12 December.
The question was as follows:
Will taxpayers with non-business wealth (such as an art collection) worth many millions of dollars be eligible for CGT rollover relief if their net business assets are less than $5 million?
The Governments answer was this:

The Government will provide Capital Gains Tax (CGT) rollover relief to small and medium sized enterprises. To be eligible for rollover relief taxpayers must satisfy a number of tests, including that the net value of the taxpayer's assets must not exceed $5 million.

For the purposes of meeting this test, an `asset' does not include, where the taxpayer is an individual who is not acting as a trustee, an asset for the personal use and enjoyment of the individual or an associate of the individual.

As a result, if an individual has an expensive antique or an art collection which is kept for the individual's personal use and enjoyment, then it will not be taken into account in determining whether the $5 million threshold is satisfied. The taxpayer will `not be eligible for rollover relief on disposal of items from the antique or art collection, as these items are not active assets in the taxpayer's business.

In light of this response from the Government the Opposition have also announced that it will be moving an amendment to ensure that such personal use items are included for the purposes of calculating the net asset value of the employer taxpayer. Why should someone with an art collection or antique collection in effect be subsidised by Australian battlers through being able to claim CGT rollover relief ?

Why shouldn't Australia's battlers be confident that if they are going to forego over $1 billion in tax revenue then their children should at least have the opportunity of a job rather than have the recipient of that tax relief add another Ming vase to their collection ?

Under the Governments proposal it will be possible for individuals who are independently wealthy in their our right and have significant accumulated wealth by virtue of their business interests to access the CGT rollover relief. We do not believe this to be fair and this amend ment goes some way to introducing some equity as to who qualifies for relief.
If the Government is going to oppose this measure I would like the Minister to explain where is the social equity for Australia's battlers in extending CGT
rollover relief to individuals when they have significant personal wealth such as an art collection, an antique collection or share portfolio.
Wouldn't it be more appropriate for that individual to divest themselves of some of their personal wealth and use that to expand their business rather than rely on taxpayers ?
Taxpayers should not be called upon to fund such an expansion just to allow someone to continue the hang the Monet in the Toorak mansion.

The final amendment to the measure the Opposition has announced is that the ATO is to monitor the amount of relief that is actually claimed and give some indication on how it has been utilised. This information is to be included in the Commissioners annual report.
With those comments in I look forward to the Governments positive response to the proposals we have put forward.
Commonwealth Education or Training Payments

I would finally add that the Opposition also has some concerns with schedule two of the Bill pertaining to the treatment of commonwealth education or training payments and that my colleague Senator Carr will be outlining these concerns and some amendments he plans to move on behalf of the Opposition in regards to these concerns.
Conclusion
In conclusion I reiterate the Oppositions position on this Bill.
The Opposition opposes the end of accelerated depreciation available on trading ships from the year 2002 to 1997.

We oppose the reduction in the invitation threshold for employee share schemes reduced from 75% of `employees' to 66% of `permanent employees' and will be moving amendments to this effect accordingly.

The Opposition will be seeking to amend the CGT small business roll over relief provisions, as we believe the Government should ensure that the tax foregone and put back into the hands small business should be used to ensure a net increase in employment by small business. As small business will save over $1 billion in Capital Gains Tax over four years, a commitment to increase employment particularly for Australia's young unemployed, the Opposition believes is not too much ask.
The Opposition will seek to move some amendments relating to schedule two of the Bill as will be outlined by Senator Carr.
The Opposition will be supporting the other provisions of the Bill.

TALK.START.PARA: —This bill is the latest in the four or five updates of the tax laws that we find ourselves considering, usually on the last day of each session. It contains a number of measures, most of which are not controversial, including streamlined rules for determining majority underlying interests in public companies, unit trusts and insurance mutuals; changes to franking rules to both class C and clause A franking credits; and technical amendments to foreign income, commercial debt forgiveness rules, tax file number provisions, and provisions relating to equity investments in small and medium sized business.

SPEECH.PARA: The bill also seeks to remove special accelerated depreciation rules for new ships introduced by the previous government and worth $40 million over the next three years. These provisions were originally introduced, along with ships capital grants, to reduce the age of the Australian shipping fleet and, it was said, thus increase its efficiency. The ships capital grants scheme was repealed by the government earlier this year and, while the Democrats opposed that repeal, the legislation passed the Senate with the support of the two Independents. The repeal of the ships capital grants scheme has rendered the depreciation provisions all but unworkable and there is little point in retaining the provisions in the Tax Act. Even though we disagree with the underlying policy we will not oppose the repeal of the depreciation provisions as that issue has already been lost with the earlier bill.

BREAK.PARA: The bill also seeks to clarify the definition of which Commonwealth education and training payments are excluded from assessable income. This is an issue the Democrats have been tracking for many years, and my colleague Senator Stott Despoja will be speaking on that matter later and moving an amendment.

The bill also implements the government's election commitments to increase the income tax exemption for employee share plan benefits from $500 a year to $1,000 a year. The Democrats have long been supporters of employee share plans which are made widely available to all employees, and we will support this initiative. The argument in favour of increasing participation in employee share plans is twofold. First, it can increase worker productivity because it gives employees a sense of ownership in the company and, second, employee share plans can help raise national savings by encouraging an employer sponsored savings mentality at the workplace.

The modelling of savings expert Dr Vince FitzGerald estimates that this encouragement of better savings behaviour at the workplace could increase the national savings ratio by up to 0.5 per cent of GDP. However, these benefits will only be available if the employee share plans are broadly based. Providing generous tax concessions, particularly by exempting up to $1,000 of income from taxation, could create a massive benefit for high income earners with access to salary packaging.

When most companies talk about employee share plans they are talking about their executive option plans where thousands of dollars of shares are given to senior executives for as little as 2c in the dollar. The Democrats do not want to provide any additional incentives for share plans which are not available to all workers. We believe that, to maximise the productivity effect and the savings effect to encourage the level of worker participation in employee share savings, plans must be available to all employees on the same terms.

For this reason, in 1995, we supported legislation which set strict criteria for an improved employee share plan. These criteria were that the plan must be made available to at least three‐quarters of all employees and that it should be offered on basically the same terms to all. We think that is fair and reasonable. As I said, we do not think this should be able to be manipulated into a generous scheme for senior highly paid employees and a less generous scheme for the rest of the workers.

However, the amendments in this bill seek to allow less fair share plans through the net. They seek to reduce the requirement that a scheme be offered to three‐quarters of all employees to a much narrower requirement of two‐thirds of permanent employees. The `permanent' means that this would allow the exclusion of virtually all of the blue collar work force from most share plans, because of the scaling down, as well as the growing proportion of employees on term contracts or on a permanent casual basis. So we oppose those amendments, as I said, for the reasons that we think the benefit should be offered as widely as possible, not to the favoured few.

The big ticket item in this bill is the introduction of capital gains tax rollover relief for small business. This measure, costing up to $200 million a year, was a key election commitment of both the Democrats and the coalition, and we welcomed it. Under the government's proposal as it currently stands the rollover relief is available only if the taxpayer's assets do not exceed $5 million. Five million dollars is a huge amount of assets. I would have preferred to have seen a much lower threshold used, as this too would have reduced the cost of the measure. A $5 million threshold means that this benefit will be available not just to small business but to a lot of medium and large sized businesses as well, because, assuming a return on assets of six to eight per cent, that amounts to assets representing an annual income of $300,000 to $400,000 a year, which is hardly your struggling corner store, or even a family farm. As a targeting measure, we believe that the government should have included personal assets in the determination of whether a small business person has net assets of $5 million and is thus eligible for this rollover relief. The Labor Party has foreshadowed amend ments on this issue and we will be supporting them.

In other respects the government's proposals were not anywhere near as generous as they should have been. The original proposal would have required the taxpayer to purchase like assets to replace the earlier asset. It would also have excluded sale of shares in the family company, insisting that the underlying assets be sold with complicated stamp duty consequences if the company sold as well. These aspects were much criticised by my colleague Senator Andrew Murray, through the Senate committees, and those concerns were put directly to the government, as they were by Mr Peter Andren MP in the other place.

On two occasions the government moved to amend its own legislation. This bill and the one we are going to debate later today, Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 3) 1997, reflect these amendments, some of which were announced in the government's response to the Bell report earlier this year. The Democrats welcome those additional concessions, but we do say they were pretty grudgingly and belatedly extended and do call into question a kind of qualified commitment of this government to the small business sector. We think a government truly committed to reducing the tax burden of compliance of small business would have comprehensively addressed not just capital gains tax but the collection of wholesale sales tax and fringe benefits tax as well.

The Senate small business taxation committee inquiry report, which was a Democrat initiative in 1995, recommended a range of such needed reforms, many of which were then recommended also by the Prime Minister's deregulation task force, headed by Mr Charlie Bell. The government has not taken these issues forward. I wait to see whether it is going to in the future. Like the development of the capital gains tax rollover relief, the few concessions that have been made we think have been made under heavy pressure from the small business lobby.

We will continue to pursue broader taxation relief for small business, which still faces average tax compliance costs two to three times those of larger business—compliance costs that are likely to increase, many say, rather than reduce if a GST is introduced. We will continue to push for further reform of small business taxes to reduce those compliance costs, seeking to ensure that the government does not use any diversionary debate about tax reform—code for a GST—to avoid its obligations to correct flaws and compliance costs in the tax code as it presently stands.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Margetts, Sen Dee

TALK.START.PARA: —The main issue of contention in the Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 1) 1997 is the treatment of scholarships and the associated issue of a draft Australian Taxation Office ruling regarding current paragraph 23(z)(i) of the Income Tax Assessment Act 1936. The majority of my comments will focus on this issue, but as briefly as I can I would like to comment on a few other issues in this omnibus bill.

SPEECH.PARA: The bill includes changes relating to the treatment of capital gains tax in a number of areas, including small and medium business, and the treatment of employee share schemes and dividend imputations. The contentious bits are a reduction of the criteria under which tax benefits are given to employee share schemes and the potential opening of capital gains tax rollovers to rorts by companies that may be part of tax minimisation structures by the wealthy. I will address these issues in the committee stage.

There are also items on dividend imputation. The education issue is the major debate and as a result we have not put to the Senate this time a proposal to decrease dividend imputation to 50 per cent. I want to flag that we will put the measure up again in future—a measure which will increase revenue by around $700 million.

The bill also includes a measure to extinguish the special depreciation on trading ships. We have an amendment designed to oppose this. We have done this because we support, as we always have, shipping and rail, despite what the government have often tried to do to the contrary. We see measure after measure targeting these industries, and we will oppose them. Further, we specifically believe it is important that Australia not be dependent upon foreign flag shipping for its transport needs in this sector. It is a dumb thing to do as a country. We think this is one sector that should get support.

On education, this bill includes what is supposedly a technical amendment to eliminate a long list of acts and replace it with the generic term `Commonwealth education or training payments', CETPs. The problem that arises is that there is some implication that this generic term includes Commonwealth tertiary scholarships. There are at least two proposed clauses that specifically imply scholarships are included. Every party here now, including the government, has put forward amendments to knock these two clauses out. The Greens, the Democrats and the government have put forward an amendment to ensure that scholarships are excluded from the definition of CETPs.

The more contentious issue the non-government parties are trying to address is the Australian Taxation Office ruling in relation to paragraph 23(z)(i) of the Income Tax Assessment Act. Subsection 23(z) quite simply says that scholarships or bursaries for `a student receiving full-time education at a school, college or university' are tax exempt. It then includes a list of exemptions, mainly exemptions relating to Commonwealth education programs like Austudy and Abstudy.

But the tricky part is paragraph 23(z)(i) which says that a scholarship is taxable if a student gets the scholarship `upon condition that the student will (or will, if required) render, or continue to render, services to that person or authority'. The devil here is in the definition of what a service is. The concept of rendering services is interpreted widely so many students, particularly in the sciences, will be seen as rendering services and be taxed.

I have a problem here in relation to the way we are funding education. I do not believe that this should be used as a means of attacking students when universities in the end are being required by government to get funding from elsewhere. In some cases, we will find that students are effectively told that, if they do applied science research or study in a cooperative research centre, their scholarship will be taxed. Yet if they do a degree in anthropology, drama or medicine, it will not be. The difference to the student might be something like $2,500 a year. So you might be penalising students in applied science or engineering and creating an incentive-disincentive system favouring degrees that are not industry relevant. This is on top of HECS and so on.

The premise by the Australian Taxation Office is that scholarships are effectively work for pay. If that were the case, then you would expect people to have all the other bits that go with working—superannuation, insurance and proper conditions. But that is not the case. What about industrial award status? No, that is not the case. They do not get overtime or superannuation contributions and they do not come under occupational health and safety. You cannot have it both ways. If it is a way of extracting money from students, who often do not have much choice, that is not the way to go.

I think we have all been trying to ensure that real scholarships are protected while addressing the situation of commercial interests fundamentally exploiting the system and ensuring that they do not get benefits. Often those commercial interests try to get students to do their research cheaply, largely subsidised by, I would say, universities and taxpayers alike. It is a problem and has not been easy. There will be amendments dealing with this in the committee stage.

We have also seen government programs explicitly set up organisations such as cooperative research centres to produce research that the government has targeted as commercially valuable. It is a case of continuing the history of trying to pick winners in technical development. It is seen, in part, as an extension of the old technology development grants, but these are explicitly part of the university system. We would like to see that those cooperative research centres are not targeted for worse treatment.

We see that there has been more of a push to privatise universities. It worked. University funding has been cut, and research funding has been cut or tied to commercialisation. Universities found that they could make up the difference by getting external funding. That is the way we have ended up going. We have ended up with a market system rather than one that is producing good academic outcomes and good research outcomes, being able to share information.

There were also issues in relation to intellectual property, and I will be dealing with those when we deal with amendments. Governments have pushed universities towards commercialism to the point that now most education, especially in the sciences and in the engineering field, is in the service of corporate profit, and almost any degree is likely to be of benefit to the private sector. Government, both Labor and Liberal, did this and fought for this. If the dividing line between education and commercial service is now a great murky swamp, a grey area, it is certainly not the students—the young people who have shown academic excellence and a willingness to work—who should be getting it in the neck. So that is what we will be trying to address in the amendments as they come into this bill.
