TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of the opposition, I would like to draw attention to some amendments that we will be moving on the issue of rendering a service in regard to the Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 1) 1997. I wish to address our concerns about the educational implications of this bill and, in particular, our concerns about the impact on the capacity for this country to develop fully fledged postgraduate research schools around the country to ensure there is an appropriate link between industry and research training and to build on our international research reputation.

SPEECH.PARA: This bill seeks to maintain existing law. The ALP amendments will be seeking to ensure that this parliament maintains the existing practice, with the protection of students and the scholarships that they currently attract. In view of the time that is available to us today to debate this important issue, I would seek leave to incorporate the remainder of my remarks.
Leave granted.

BREAK.PARA: The speech read as follows—

I am speaking on this bill in relation to its impact on education. We are dealing here with what is essentially a very simple issue: whether we, as a nation, want to encourage post‐graduate research, to improve links between industry and research training, and to maintain and build on our international research reputation. This bill claims that it seeks to maintain existing law. The ALP amendments seek to ensure that this parliament maintains the existing practice.

The Income Tax Assessment Act states that scholarships are tax exempt, except where the recipient is required to `render a service' to the scholarship provider. Although this is a legal provision of longstanding application, the practice has been that post‐graduate scholarships have not been subject to tax. In other words, the `rendering services' test has not been rigorously applied by the Tax Office in the past.

In 1994, the Tax Office took steps preparatory to enforcing the `rendering a service' provision. It issued a draft tax ruling which sought to define `rendering a service'. This would have forced every recipient to apply to the Tax Office in order to determine whether or not their scholarship was exempt—hardly an incentive for the provision of research scholarships.

The initial Draft Ruling provided a list of the sorts of activities which would be considered by the Tax Office as `services rendered'. According to the Draft Ruling, simply acknowledging the scholarship provider in a report or publication of results would be considered to be rendering a service.

The ALP believes that was an unreasonable interpretation. Over and above that, however, we believe that to try to determine the tax status of a scholarship on this basis is a flawed approach, doing nothing but creating concern and confusion among the very people we want to be involved in important research work. If the Draft Ruling were implemented, these people would be bogged down in ongoing debates with the Tax Office about whether or not they were `rendering a service' for the receipt of their scholarship.

After detailed consultations with the relevant parts of the education sector, the ALP has decided that the `rendering a service' provision should be removed, to make it clear that genuine scholarships should be tax exempt, without the need for any further justification. We believe that the way the system has been effectively operating for some years, with the `services rendered' provision not being enforced, or not in any serious or systematic way, is a good indication of the soundness of this approach.

We do not believe that a definition of scholarship needs to be enshrined in the law. We feel that, in this case, definitions are likely to place unforeseen limits on what will be judged to be a scholarship. And, given that this is a very simple issue, as I have already said, about encouraging research scholarships, then we ought to be seeking the broadest possible definition. On one hand, the revenue estimated from this measure is $6 million per annum. On the other, there is a real possibility of damage to national research effort.

If the Tax Office view was implemented there would be a further disincentive for low income earners without private means to undertake post‐graduate study. This would disadvantage those who rely upon scholarships to support themselves. It has to be remembered this is all the more significant for post‐graduate students with dependants.

Further attacks on equitable access to higher education, building upon the assault in last year's budget increases in HECS, which included acceleration of HECS repayments and the introduction of full fees for undergraduates.

We do not believe that the amendment circulated by Senator Stott Despoja is necessary. The Tax Office has already indicated in its draft rulings that it does not believe that payments received by a student in his or her capacity as an employee rather than as a student are by way of qualifying as a scholarship.
It has also indicated that it considers a scholarship to be a grant made primarily for the education of the student.

We think that is entirely reasonable. We believe that, where this Parliament needs to give guidance is not on the question of what constitutes a scholarship but on the issue of rendering a service. We think that it needs to be made crystal clear that this is not a valid test of whether or not a payment is to be considered a scholarship. Under those circumstances, the best way to achieve this is simply to strike out the paragraph.
Where does the Government stand in all this?
The Higher Education Funding Report for the 1997‐99 Triennium, put out in the name of the Minister, Senator Vanstone, contains the following paragraph:

`The Government stated in its pre‐election higher education policy statement that it desires to attract industry support for post‐graduate research scholarships. However, the Government is concerned at suggestions that such scholarships might be taxable and is aware of the need to clarify the tax status of industry linked post‐graduate research scholarships. Options for taxation treatment of these scholarships are currently being considered'.
Well, Minister, what is the result of the Government's considerations? What action will you be taking to ensure that post‐graduate research scholarships are not taxed and research is encouraged?

The amendment you have circulated does not do this. It does not address the substantive issue, that is, the tax status of post‐graduate scholarships which are likely to be caught by the `rendering a service' provision.

That is not the path Australia should take. Professor Ron MacDonald, Pro Vice‐Chancellor (research) at the University of Newcastle, was reported in the Sydney Morning Herald of 1 April as saying that the applying the tax as proposed in the draft ruling would make doctorate students `the best qualified but poorest paid workers in Australia'.

The President of the Business/Higher Education Round Table, Mr Ashley Goldsworthy—someone I would think you would want to listen to—was reported in the Financial Review of 9 May as saying as tax on scholarships was `counterproductive'.

Two professional accountancy bodies, the Australian Society of Certified Practising Accountants and the Institute of Chartered Accounts in Australia, in their submissions to the West review, argue for greater collaborative ties with industry and recommend a stronger post‐graduate research effort and more scholarships.
Australia's future does not lie in hindering the research effort. Yet the Government has not acted to fix the problem, but it can, by supporting our amendments.

If it does not, we know what that means. It means that, yet again, Senator Vanstone has let the bean counters win. She has let them jeopardise the future of this country for short‐term so‐called `savings' for which we or our children will pay the real price in years to come. That price will higher than any sums which she, as Minister against Education, has offered up on the altar of slash and burn government, as substantial as those sums have been. That price will be downgraded universities, poorer quality education, reduced access for all but the wealthy, a run‐down national research effort, and a generation of young people ill‐equipped to take their place in the new workplace and society.

One thing that can definitely be said about Senator Vanstone's time as Minister is that at least she has been consistent. She has consistently lost every battle to maintain sensible funding levels in one of the most vital areas of government expenditure. She has consistently and unremittingly failed Australia in the important task entrusted to her. Today, the Government has a chance to change that miserable record, by supporting the ALP amendments.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Stott Despoja, Sen Natasha

TALK.START.PARA: —My concerns, and those of the Democrats, with the tax laws bills are aimed at achieving clarification so that true scholarships are exempt from taxation. We believe that exempting scholarships from taxation goes to the very foundation of our education tradition. Certainly the Australian Democrats believe that education should be available to all Australians, regardless of sex, age, health, background, racial or ethnic origin or place of residence.

SPEECH.PARA: We also believe that education is a lifelong process and all education is of value. We believe education has an increasingly import ant place in a rapidly changing and multidimensional world. These multidimensions require human beings to adapt and confidently deal with the new circumstances through improvisation and an understanding of change. So it is in this context that scholarships are available to assist and reward the developments of a person's talents. The benefits can be in art work, new ideas, a new angle to an old theme or an achievement, and the list of possibilities goes on.

The history of the taxing provision provides an interesting insight into what the scholarship exemption was supposed to achieve. In 1950, the Spooner committee reported to the Treasurer at the time, the Rt Hon. A.W. Fadden. The terms of reference of the committee were to examine the desirability of exempting scholarship income from taxation. At the time, England and New Zealand exempted scholarships from tax.

The committee concluded that payments in the form of `awards to enable students to pursue a course of study' should be exempt, while payments in the nature of remuneration for present and future services and living allowances should be taxed. The committee proposed an amendment to section 23 of the Income Tax Assessment Act 1936, and the words they suggested are informative. They suggested the section should be amended to exclude tax on:
. . . the income arising from a fellowship, scholarship or bursary held by a person receiving instruction at a university, college, school or other educational establishment.

This recommendation was implemented an as an amendment to the Income Tax Assessment Act 1936, using the words as they presently appear in this act in subsection 23(z). It is notable that the words in paragraph 23(z)(i) were different from the Spooner committee recommendations. They introduced the terms which have resulted in the uncertainty and concerns I have with this provision. They introduced the rendering services, which were not recommended by the Spooner committee.

Since that time, the education sector has undergone considerable change. The attacks by both the former government and the current government on the sector are, I think, eroding the sector and perhaps moving the divide between educational purposes and industry purposes closer together. This blurring has resulted in this present difficulty distinguishing between work and study. The rendering services interpretation will now mean that many scholarships which were not previously taxed will be taxed because students are doing the research of industry.
The coalition's higher education policy statement of February 1996 stated:

The Coalition desires to attract industry support for postgraduate research scholarships and is concerned at suggestions that up to Australian Postgraduate Award limits such scholarships might be taxable.

The bill will enact the exact opposite of the coalition's election policy; that is, by imposing a tax on most scholarships. This conclusion is inevitable, given the taxation commissioner's draft tax ruling which will make scholarships which are presently tax free taxable.

The amendments that the Australian Democrats are proposing remove the offending rendering services provision and in its place substitute words which will distinguish between the employer-employee relationship and ensure students are not studying what they should be paid as a worker to do. Governments have blurred study and work, and these amendments are directed at solving that problem.

The process of achieving these amendments has involved a lot of consultation and a lot of canvassing—certainly the views of a broad range of the community. I have also consulted with many members in this place. Some amendments were circulated many weeks ago. I have consulted young people and graduates and students—those people whose lives will be affected by reduced income—and I have expressed their views through a range of e-mails and letters and, of course, petitions. We have had thousands of signatories to the petition that we circulated in this place.
I have a number of letters from students and graduates who are concerned about the proposed changes. I seek leave to table those, rather than express them here today.
Leave granted.

BREAK.PARA: In general terms, the social policy program is one of encouraging suitably qualified students to pursue higher degrees in the belief that it will be of great benefit to Australia in terms of the intellectual capital it provides the country as well the creation of a large pool of highly educated individuals who will contribute to society through later employment.

I have also consulted with people in the industry sector who say that imposing a tax will increase their administrative costs with more paperwork, and provide a disincentive to further education upon which they rely to carry out their businesses. The government, they believe, is actively trying to encourage greater participation by industry in research. Through scholarships, industry can contribute to education as well as assist in the collaboration the government talks about. I have also consulted various people in the postgraduate and educational sector and the universities and their representative organisations such as the Council of Australian Postgraduate Associations, the National Tertiary Education Union, the Australian Vice‐Chancellors Committee, the CRC Committee and FASTS. The proposed amendments will do just that, but they will also ensure that students are not studying what they should be paid as a worker to do. I have also consulted with other parties and discussed with them the various solutions to this problem. Of course, there have been a number of negotiations and consultations with the government in order to achieve a workable solution. The amendment that I am proposing today on behalf of the Australian Democrats is, we believe, a good solution. It addresses the main concerns that I have discussed today. I hope the government and the other parties will support the amendments before them today.

SPEECH.PARA: The opposition is quite concerned about the impact of this bill in regard to the effect on scholarships for postgraduate awards and scholarships for those undertaking postgraduate work, which are funded by private industry. We are particularly concerned as a result of the confusion that has arisen from the 1994 tax office draft ruling on the issue of rendering of service. We believe that the interpretation that has been pursued by the tax office is not an appropriate one and that this parliament ought to provide advice to the tax office to clarify this situation.

According to the draft ruling, simply acknowledging the scholarship provider in a report or publication would be considered to be rendering a service, therefore just about anybody undertaking postgraduate work and having their work published may in fact be subject to this interpretation. The Labor opposition believes that this is an unreasonable interpretation. Over and above that, however, we think that to try to determine the tax status of a scholarship on the basis of a flawed approach is doing nothing to create anything other than concern and confusion amongst the very people we are relying upon to provide this country with an essential part of its research work. If the draft ruling is implemented, we are likely to see quite serious disincentives being provided to people trying to undertake postgraduate research.

BREAK.PARA: Our concerns have been as a result of detailed consultations that we have undertaken with relevant sections of the education industry and the grave concern that has been expressed by the representative groups of students in the postgraduate research areas. We believe that you do not need a definition of a scholarship to be enshrined in the law itself. While this bill, as I said earlier, seeks to maintain the existing law, what we do need defined is a mechanism to protect the existing practice. We feel that definitions are likely to place unforeseen limits on what might in fact be regarded as a scholarship. This would open it up to all sorts of confusion and further disincentives in terms of students undertaking research scholarships.

The tax office has already indicated in its draft rulings that it does not believe that the payments received by a student in his or her capacity as an employee rather than a student are by way of qualifying as a scholarship. We have indicated that, as far as we are concerned, the tax office consideration of scholarship to be granted made primarily for the education of a student is an appropriate way to proceed. We think that is an entirely reasonable basis on which to make a judgment.

We believe that this parliament needs, however, to provide further guidance to the tax office on, not so much the issue of what constitutes a scholarship, but what it means to render a service. We think it needs to be crystal clear that there is not a valid test of whether or not a payment is to be considered a scholarship. The shift in employment practice has increasingly been designed to facilitate the just in time or `hollow' factory management practice. In effect, the ship that brings in the materials should be able to take away the finished product almost immediately in response to an order for the goods.

Technically it is now possible as a management strategy, and basically materials are fairly secure. Computers and modern communications allow the data management required to implement such schemes and modern computer production equipment allows the rapid direction of equipment. The problem with the `hollow' factory is that the management treats labour as another input, particularly as low‐skilled labour. Companies want the option to call on workers for a contract and dismiss them afterwards—`hollow' includes a hollowness in terms of employees. In addition, there are various reasons why it is to the advantage of companies to be able to dismiss employees or employ them under terms given under a different status to real, that is, full‐time, employees.

We think this proposal by the government is going to exacerbate the practices we think are not leading in the right direction. SPEECH.PARA: (1) The Commissioner must monitor the amount of roll‐over relief granted under this Division in a financial year and include particulars of that amount in the annual report under section 14 for that year.

In respect of this set of amendments, our intention is to seek to link the granting of capital gains tax rollover relief to employment growth quite directly. Unless the taxpayer can demonstrate, upon the sale and purchase of a new business during the 12‐month period following the acquisition of a new business employment, that growth has increased by 10 per cent compared to the business that was sold, the CGT rollover would not be granted.

We are applying two tests when determining whether the 10 per cent target has been met: either a 10 per cent increase in full‐time equivalent employee hours or a 10 per cent increase in the aggregate payroll paid for by the employer in the form of salaries and wages. We believe these incentives will provide a direct link between the tax concessionality being offered—the rollover relief—and employment.

These amendments will ensure that the $1.2 billion of tax relief is put directly to achieving a good social outcome: namely, the generation of employment. We do not believe that $1.2 billion in tax relief should be given on the basis of a wish or on the basis of an assumption that employment will grow, particularly when that is the stated claim behind this tax change.

This is a massive tax change. It is very significant. The Prime Minister, Mr Howard, has said on a number of occasions, as has the Treasurer, that it must generate more employment. We are linking this directly to the generation of employment. We say to small business, `Good on you. You receive this $1.2 billion tax relief. Good on you if you can increase your employment by at least 10 per cent.' We do not believe that is a big ask, given the stated intention of this provision, given its rationale and given the very significant sum of money involved, which is effectively a transfer from the public sector to the small business sector in the form of tax relief.

The other amendments we are dealing with in this schedule alter the net business asset test. The effect will be to turn this into a net assets test by including a provision that the personal use assets of the taxpayer will be included for the purposes of the test. This is the personal use, not the business assets. The only exclusion to this will be personal use assets that have a value of $5,000 or less which will be excluded from the test. This is consistent with the treatment of personal use assets as contained in the capital gains tax provisions under the tax act.

BREAK.PARA: The effect of these amendments will be to include personal wealth assets such as art collections, antique collections, yachts and very expensive residences. We do not believe that, when calculating the assets for the purposes of this measure—which is a very extensive tax concession involving $1.2 billion of tax change—these types of personal assets should be excluded.
I recall asking Senator Kemp on 12 December last year a question on notice concerning this capital gains tax rollover relief. I asked Senator Kemp:
Will taxpayers with non‐business wealth (such as an art collection) worth many millions of dollars be eligible for CGT rollover relief if their net business assets are less than $5 million?
The Assistant Treasurer answered:

The Government will provide Capital Gains Tax (CGT) rollover relief to small and medium sized enterprises. To be eligible for rollover relief taxpayers must satisfy a number of tests, including that the net value of the taxpayer's assets must not exceed $5 million.

For the purposes of meeting this test, an `asset' does not include, where the taxpayer is an individual who is not acting as a trustee, an asset for the personal use and enjoyment of the individual or an associate of the individual. As a result, if an individual has an expensive antique or art collection, which is kept for the individual's personal use and enjoyment, then it will not be taken into account in determining whether the $5 million threshold is satisfied.
We are saying it should be taken into account. Senator Kemp went on to say:
The taxpayer will not be eligible for rollover relief on disposal of items from the antique or art collection, as these items are not active assets in a taxpayer's business.

However, different rules apply if an individual is acting as a trustee. For example, where a trust owns both business assets and other assets (such as antiques or works of art), the value of all of the assets owned by the trust will be taken into account in determining whether the $5 million threshold is satisfied.

The requirement that employment or total payroll paid must increase by 10 per cent is arbitrary and can be difficult to meet in the short term. The provisions would be unfair during any economic downturn and when employment growth is sluggish. I stress that accepting these provisions would lead to a significant degree of complexity in the tax law. In turn this would increase the compliance and administration costs for small business and may only result in creating addition al jobs for the Australian Taxation Office to administer the provisions. The opposition's requirements relating to the average number of employees and the aggregate payroll would be very difficult to comply with and impossible to administer in multiple disposals. The opposition's amendments are based on the presumption that the CGT rollover relief for small business will not facilitate the creation of new jobs. There has been no evidence put forward to support this. In fact, evidence suggests that small business is the engine room for the creation of new jobs in the economy and the government has placed considerable importance on facilitating its expansion.

A recent BIE publication entitled `Industry Brief September 1995' has shown that small businesses have been the major generators of new jobs in the Australian economy since the mid‐1980s. The government has specifically designed the rollover relief measure so that there is a bias towards employment creating activities, that is, rollover relief is only available where the capital gain is invested in active income generating assets, not passive assets. So we will be opposing the amendments put forward by the opposition in relation to the employment test, for the reasons that I have stated, not the least of which is the major problems which will occur in relation to compliance and the arbitrary nature of them.

The opposition has proposed that personal assets be included in the $5 million threshold for access to rollover relief. I think, even with a subsequent amendment that has been proposed, the person in small business will still be forced to value their personal assets and the increase in compliance costs which is involved.

These are the measures which were proposed in our election policy. They were very popular messages and the government believes they enjoy very wide support in the community. Small business is waiting for these measures to go through. We urge the Senate to support the government's position.

TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Opposition in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —The bill proposes to enact the decision to terminate the infrastructure borrowings—IB—scheme introduced by Labor as part of the One Nation statement. Private investors had long complained that the tax system was biased against the private provision of infrastructure. So Labor listened and introduced the IB scheme.

SPEECH.PARA: The IB scheme involves assisting private sector involvement in various infrastructure projects by modifying the tax system. This private sector investment was historically impeded because the initial years' losses generated by most—or all—of the projects could not be offset against the other income of the investors unless the project was undertaken by a single investor only as part of a wholly owned company group.

The sheer size of most infrastructure projects, worth either hundreds of millions or billions of dollars, meant that no Australian company was big enough—or very rarely big enough—to undertake the project on their own. Of course, it is generally commercially advantageous to have partners as they provide expertise in various specialist aspects of the project—for example, finance, construction, engineering services—so it is natural that most projects would be undertaken by consortia. These projects, though, would then confront the tax problem I mentioned before.

The IBs overcame this problem by reducing the cost of infrastructure finance by effectively transferring the tax benefit of the tax deductibility of interest from the borrower to the lender. This was achieved by making the interest non-deductible to the borrower and either non-assessable to the lender or assessable but subject to a rebate equal to the company tax rate. This allowed a reduction of the rate in interest that lenders will charge borrowers for infrastructure projects.

Projects were assessed by a statutory authority—the Development Allowance Authority, which is at arms length to government—on their merit and according to the statutory criteria. This system was starting to function very effectively as an incentive and as leverage for significant projects, which may not have been delivered for many years—if at all—due to budgetary conditions in the public sector.

That said, there were some problems. For example, Labor announced that IBs would cease to be available for urban road projects from late 1995, a decision that was later overturned by the Treasurer (Mr Costello). Secondly, there is some evidence that aggressive tax planning was creeping into the marketing of IBs at the retail level. These were matters that warranted being addressed by the government. However, the Treasurer's announcement in February was an over‐reaction.

On 14 February 1997, Treasurer Costello announced the government's intention to: prevent the lodging of any new IB applications; prevent the certification of any more projects under the IB arrangements, including those currently before the certification authority—the Development Allowance Authority; and, thirdly, terminate the right of variation of the conditions attaching to existing IBs where the Tax Commissioner considers this may cause an increased cost to the revenue.

Quite literally, he cut the IB program off at the knees, head, arms—the lot. There were no warnings, no apologies to those who were not seeking to rort the system. There was no respect for the continuation of normal pro cessing of applications. No thought was given to the impact of the decisions on the applicants, nor of the delays, nor the effect on the regions where the infrastructure is planned.

During the press conference the Treasurer also flagged that alternative arrangements for infrastructure would be announced in the 1997-98 budget. The new replacement program has now been announced and it is completely inadequate. I will return to this matter later.

The pretence under which the Treasurer acted was that there was a serious threat to revenue. What he did not say was that there is already an effective mechanism to cap the revenue cost of the measure—indeed it is a measure that he himself invoked in September 1996. He then claimed that the provisions could be rorted. Labor has stated that we will support any clampdown on rorts, and we will, but the complete cessation of the current program is an over‐reaction. At the press conference the Treasurer stated:

The Development Allowance Authority has received legal advice to say that it is not able to refuse certification on the grounds that they are providing undue tax benefits and, as a result, the government will enact legislation effective from midday today which will prevent any of those applications being certified.

So instead of saying that the government will amend the law to grant a discretion to the DAA to reject any applications which are too tax aggressive, the Treasurer used this as a pretence to shut down the whole scheme. This is despite the fact that Mr Costello specifically acknowledged at the same press conference:

I want to keep stressing not every IB scheme is like what I've described today. There are a lot of IB schemes which are straight up and down in accordance with the spirit and the letter of the law and you know they are people trying to do the right thing and they're getting good investment infrastructure. I want to stress that point.

The Treasurer's approach to this is duplicitous and, frankly, approaching a con. If you want to obtain savings from a tax expenditure, claim that it is being rorted. Then don't simply tighten the scheme to address any problems, cut the scheme completely to produce savings. Then if anybody wishes to analyse the alleged problems, or seeks actual evidence of the claimed rorting, assert that they are supporting tax avoidance. This was the model pursued with the research and development syndication concession and it is also being put in this case.

Despite this over‐reaction, Labor does not seek to defeat the bill. We recognise that the government has made an announcement and this, in practice, has been implemented. It has thrown the existing rules into chaos but we cannot now undo that chaos.

That said, we are concerned about the need for transitional provisions to assist some genuine projects which were: firstly, well advanced along the certification process; secondly, not aimed at rorting the tax system; and, thirdly, going to provide desirable regional development opportunities. This was one of the key issues which has been considered by the Senate committee which examined the legislation.

Why should people who have done the right thing be penalised? Why should Australia's reputation as a stable place to invest and do business be threatened as it has been in this instance? Which projects have now been threatened by cutting off the scheme?

There were many worthwhile projects. Some examples of those were given in evidence before the Senate committee. They included the Redbank power project, which is an important project for the Hunter region, which is proposing to pioneer in Australia a relatively environmentally friendly electricity production process using coal waste.

The New South Wales central‐west gas pipeline project is a proposal to build a 255‐kilometre open access natural gas pipeline from Marsden to Forbes, Parkes, Narromine and Dubbo. It is now in doubt because of the termination of the IB scheme. And there is a further 300‐kilometre extension of that pipeline, which would connect Dubbo to Tamworth, with laterals to Gunnedah, Gulgong and Mudgee and worth $45 million, similarly threatened.

There are many other projects which have been unfairly treated under the Treasurer's decision. I mention these two as examples only. I also mention them to make the point that there are two categories of projects from the point of view of the opposition: those that we can assist by amending this legislation, such as Redbank. And I think there is another project in Queensland, a Queensland gas power station known as Oakey; and, regrettably, those that we cannot assist.

We can assist the Redbank and another few projects by seeking to overturn the most pernicious aspect of the bill, namely, the retrospective nullification of the certification of projects that has occurred since the Treasurer's announcement in February.

Incredibly, this bill seeks to overturn some arm's‐length decisions already taken by the Development Allowance Authority according to the current law. That approach is indefensible, as this is effectively political interference in investment decisions that regrettably does occur in some other countries around the world. The government should be ashamed of itself for the message that political interference sends out to the international investor community.

The government is not merely proposing to change the rules midway through the game. It is proposing to change the result after the game has ended. The opposition cannot support such an outrageous proposal, and I will move amendments in the committee stage to overturn these proposed provisions.

Unfortunately, the opposition cannot assist the other projects which are caught in the decision making pipeline but for which a decision has not been made by the DAA. While we deplore the treatment of these projects, they have not yet been certified and it is not the proper function of the Senate to attempt to favour some uncertified projects over others, no matter what may be the public good and the merit in some of those uncertified projects. However, the opposition will look very closely at the new scheme.

The government's new scheme was announced in the budget. It was not announced with much fanfare because it is a pale imitation of the arrangements it seeks to replace. Frankly, like everything else in the budget, it disappeared very quickly. It is called the `infrastructure borrowing tax rebate' but it really should not be so broadly characterised. It is not a general scheme to assist the provision of private infrastructure in Australia; it is targeted only at land transport projects, although those projects which were left in limbo on 14 February are allowed to apply.

The limitations seem extraordinary, given that in the same budget we are told that for the savings rebate it is wrong to favour any one type of saving and we must benefit all types equally. It is an incredibly different application of principle.

Secondly, the administration has been transferred to the Tax Commissioner from the DAA. While Labor has no problem with the involvement of the Tax Commissioner on specific tax matters, I am not sure what expertise the commissioner will bring to the question of infrastructure. Indeed, I wonder if the commissioner wants yet another area of responsibility on top of his considerable current responsibilities—additional complexity and cost.

The third area of change will be the reduction in the rate of concession that will apply to superannuation funds and other taxpayers that face lower nominal rates of tax than the company tax rate. Labor specifically made IBs more attractive to super funds through the 36 per cent rebate option. This was working in attracting finance from some super funds into infrastructure. These changes may put that trend at risk. It continues the inexplicable attack on superannuation that has been engaged in by this current Treasurer.

The fourth—and arguably the most important—change has been the totally inadequate funding allocation to the concession. The government is allocating $37.5 million in 1997‐98 and $75 million in subsequent years. This contrasted with $200 million that Labor had allocated to our IB program.

Clearly, many or most of the projects that have been left in limbo will not fit into the tiny allocation. In any event, it appears that there will be no approvals of projects under the new arrangements until 1 January 1998.

I will not detain the Senate any more on this issue. I will be speaking briefly in committee. I do understand the pressures for time on the Senate, but we have had to make what are the very basic and minimal contributions in the debate, and will do so again in the committee stage.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Margetts, Sen Dee

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: At the end of the motion, add "but the Senate calls on the Government:
(a) to give priority in the timing of its consideration of the four projects which were given certification after the termination of the old scheme;
(b) to deal with the applications expeditiously; and

(c) to strongly consider during its approval process the environmental implications of all applications under the new scheme, and particularly the implications of decisions on Australia's ability to meet likely future Greenhouse obligations agreed by the majority of other nations".

This Taxation Laws Amendment (Infrastructure Borrowings) Bill has been a vexed issue for the Greens, as I think it has been for a number of people. Initially, the Greens (WA) were strong opponents of the infrastructure borrowings scheme, especially when it was the provision of incentives and benefits for the private sector owned infrastructure that would be used as an alternative to, or replacement for, public sector infrastructure: private power plants, private motorways, tollways and so on. Even before I was a senator I was speaking out on this issue in relation to the subsidy to the Collie coal‐fired power station.

As the scheme evolved, the funding of roads lost favour, and the scheme began to be used to fund some fairly good projects: co‐generation, sewage and water treatment plants. As the public sector in power and water was privatised in a wholesale manner, the implications of giving advantages to desirable projects also changed. In a private sector context, to give advantages to projects that are less polluting or that address environmental problems is worthwhile, if the discrimination about what is good for the environment is done with integrity—and that is important.

In short, we think the infrastructure borrowings scheme was moving in the right direction, although in our opinion it still fell well short of what we would have liked. It could be a tool for promoting appropriate and less ecologically damaging infrastructure. The government now wants to cut the scheme and devise a new one that will effectively replicate the original bad scheme, to be primarily used to give support for private roadways, motorways and tollways as well as rail projects. As such, the Greens (WA) will strongly oppose it when it reaches the Senate.

I give notice right now that we will try to amend it by taking out any support for roads and putting in support for rail and for energy projects such as co‐generation and development of power specifically from renewable resources. We would also seek to include projects for high level cleaning of sewage and waste water, especially energy efficient projects. The dumping of sewage waste and waste water into our fresh water systems is not supportable, and we should be doing things which are going in the right direction.

The old infrastructure borrowing provisions, as I said, were problematic but improving; and the new scheme, as formulated, is a retrograde disaster. In this context we are also asked to decide on the fate of four projects which have been certified but are not included in the current scheme because the certification came too late. The ALP has an amendment to allow them to be included. We know that there is a measure of justice in that, in the sense that these industries have planned and proceeded on the expectation that their efforts would not be invalidated by Treasury fiat at the last moment. On the other hand the aged, the poor and students plan their lives on the expectation that a given fee regime or benefit regime will apply.

We also know that indication was given to various applicants originally that they should not go any further. So, if we were to support the four that did push on, even though they were told the scheme was no longer effective, we would potentially be discriminating against those people who chose to take the advice that the scheme was no longer operative.

Nevertheless, we are prepared to listen to an undertaking by the minister to deal with these projects expeditiously. We have circulated a second reading amendment to that effect, calling for those projects that have already been certified to be given priority in the timing of their reconsideration under the new scheme. I am not asking that they be given priority for approval, just that they be first in terms of what schemes are considered. I think that is fair. The amendment also says that the Senate asks for these schemes to be dealt with expeditiously, which again is only fair, particularly if we are not supporting the ALP amendment to allow them to qualify under the old scheme—which, I have to say, we will not be doing.

Part of the problem for us was that not all of the schemes are ones that we are entirely happy with. I have to say that, in particular, it is interesting that Redbank has been argued on environmental grounds. The arguments are convoluted, and the project has been opposed by the Newcastle Greens, Greenpeace and the Total Environment Centre. On the other hand, they argue that it is a project that produces emission levels worse than those of other black coal plants and that it displaces cleaner coal and perpetuates coal burning. They feel it will be a technology applied to other coal plants and so will increase their emission levels.

The project proponents argue that emission levels will now be better than other black coal plants in Victoria. But, in reality, what we end up with is that Redbank may create a more competitive situation for black coal, at the cost of increasing emissions and burning coal in an overall dirtier way. In all, we do not think that the arguments on environment hold better. On the other hand, the Greens feel that making minor technical improvements to undesirable technology is not necessarily a step forward. There are better ways of producing power: gas as an interim source, and renewables as the preferred option. There should be a cap on coal fired and diesel power of all sorts. It is simply not smart in the current international regime for Australia to be seen to be continuing to hand out incentives to people who are in fact not moving in the right direction in relation to greenhouse gas production.

I do not think we can or should create special cases for coal fired power. The project should be considered expeditiously, but power stations based on gas power—and, in the case of Parkeston, based on replacing diesel fired power—will go ahead, although Oakey would do better in competition with dirtier power if it were given the same infrastructure borrowing benefits. There are other issues, such as the Port Stephens sewerage plant which might go ahead with stage one but not stage two, and I note that there is some community objection to that project.

In short, I do not agree with claims that there are overriding environmental reasons to support the inclusion of all of those projects under the old scheme. I am prepared to let them be considered under the new scheme; but, as it might be said: `If it were done, when `tis done, then `twere well it were done quickly'. I commend my second reading amendment to the Senate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kernot, Sen Cheryl

TALK.START.PARA: —The Taxation Laws Amendment (Infrastructure Borrowings) Bill puts into legislation the intention of the government to close down the infrastructure borrowing scheme which was introduced by the former Labor government. When Treasurer Costello announced that, the Democrats welcomed it. We reminded others that EPAC found there was no real need for the scheme, because there was no tax disadvantage for private sector infrastructure. In fact, EPAC went so far as to say the money would be better spent by putting more into the public provision of infrastructure which it could do more cheaply than the private sector could over the medium term.

SPEECH.PARA: The National Commission of Audit set up by this government came to a similar view, and concluded that the tax arrangements needed to be reviewed. Following the audit commission recommendations, over the next three months the body responsible for the infrastructure borrowing concessions, the Development Allowance Authority, was—we are told—inundated with applications. By September it had 71 applications for a total investment of $21 billion, an estimated tax cost of $4 billion. This was well in excess of the $200 million per year the government had capped for assistance under this scheme. On 10 September 1996, the Treasurer directed the DAA to take no further applications. On 14 February 1997, the Treasurer announced that legislation would be introduced to prevent the DAA from issuing any further certificates unless they were subject to an undertaking, and the Democrats supported that decision.

The Labor Party has proposed some interesting amendments to ensure that four projects, which continued to insist on having certificates issued by the DAA even though the Treasurer had closed down the scheme, should be grandfathered. There are some very important competing principles here: the principle of retrospectivity and the principle of legislation effecting good environmental outcomes. That is a particular concern with respect to the Redbank power station. However, I am going to listen carefully to the arguments from the Labor Party on these matters.

We support the closure of the infrastructure bonds scheme. It was one of the most dubious ideas ever dreamt up by the former Keating government. It was never a fair or a cost effective measure. Certainly, it was not an effective alternative to reversing the massive decline in public sector investment in infrastructure. I might add, though, that we think the Howard government's plan to replace it with an even smaller scheme just for road and rail, worth $75 million a year, while at the same time reducing spending on public sector infrastructure by a massive $948 million—that is $75 million to $948 million next year—is just as dubious a policy.

The country needs modern, efficient infrastructure as an essential base for economic development. Tax breaks to make others do what is essentially the responsibility of governments are not the most cost‐effective way of achieving it. Those afraid to embrace the need to broaden the revenue raising base of this country find themselves without the money to do what is necessary and without the political will to tackle it. I do not think a GST is the answer to this particular problem, if you are going to quote tax reform, Senator Kemp.

The Democrats support the second reading amendment moved by Senator Margetts. I think it makes some really important points in principle, but it does not require the Treasurer to do anything about it. We are making an important statement of principle. It would be much better if the Treasurer would turn around and say, `We'll be guided by these principles in the future', but nothing is convincing me that he is going to respond in that way.
We commend the bill and we will listen carefully to the Labor Party's arguments in the committee stage.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kemp, Sen Rod

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the senators for their contributions. Quite a range of remarks were made and it will not surprise senators to note that the government did not agree with all of them, particularly the range of remarks included in Senator Sherry's speech.

SPEECH.PARA: Nonetheless, the government appreciates the interest that people have in this important bill. In view of the time constraints, I want to address my remarks to the central issue raised by the Greens and Senator Kernot and Senator Sherry.

The government, let me say, appreciates the sentiment in the second reading amendment moved by the Greens. However, it has some problems in accepting the whole of the amendment. Let me make it clear that the government announced in the budget a replacement scheme for the infrastructure borrowing arrangements in the form of an infrastructure borrowings rebate. In announ cing the rebate scheme, the government stated:

The program will be open for applications for assistance in respect of private land transport infrastructure projects; project proponents which had applied for an IBs certificate by 12 p.m. (by legal time in the Australian Capital Territory), 14 February 1997; and extensions of projects that had been certified to use IBs.

The four projects referred to by senators will therefore be eligible to apply for assistance under the new rebate scheme. Given the advanced stage of these projects when the announcement was made to abolish the existing infrastructure borrowings scheme, the government considers that these projects should be given priority consideration under the new scheme. That deals with one of the central issues that were raised by a number of senators in the second reading debate.

In relation to the process for assessing applications, the government has established criteria which must be properly assessed. In relation to the third element of the Greens' proposal, it will generally be the case that these projects would not proceed without environmental assessment.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am conscious of the significant time constraints we are under. In my speech during the second reading debate I believe I outlined the reasons why the two amendments we are considering in the committee stage should be passed. The effect of the amendments is to allow those four projects which had applied to the DAA and had been certified to receive the infrastructure concession. Because they were approved and had followed due process, they should be permitted to receive the concession under the legislation.

SPEECH.PARA: I think Senator Margetts and Senator Brown misunderstand the process that the Treasurer (Mr Costello) followed. In my speech during the second reading debate I outlined that we fundamentally do not think it is the Treasurer's right to strike out the process; it is the parliament's right. Indeed, it is the parliament's obligation to strike out the process. It is not up to the Treasurer to decree by press release that, as from that day forthwith, no further projects can be considered by the DAA. That is effectively what he has done. We are asking the parliament and the Senate to approve that process.

We cannot accept that, as a principle, the Treasurer can get up at any time and, by decree in a press release, say, `Forthwith, in terms of the legal process which is being followed'—in this case by the DAA, but in any other case by perhaps a tribunal or a court—`it is our policy that we do not agree. This process should stop today,' even though, legally, the process is required to go on until this parliament approves the cessation of the process. We cannot support that in principle.

The Greens may have environmental concerns about some of these projects. It is apparent from the second reading amendment moved by Senator Margetts that the Greens have concerns about one such project. The second reading amendment refers to:
. . . the implications of decisions on Australia's ability to meet likely future Greenhouse obligations agreed by the majority of other nations.
I refer to the case in point—Redbank.

For the Senate record, the Singleton Shire Council issued a development consent for the project in 1994, with 47 conditions. The council's action followed a year‐long process of environmental assessment and public comment. Greenpeace appealed to the New South Wales Land and Environment Court, questioning the need for power and the projected CO2 emissions. There was a full trial on the merits, lasting more than a week, held before Justice Pearlman.
After finding that the council's actions were not contrary to the national greenhouse reduction strategy, the Chief Justice drew the following conclusions:

All these matters led, in my opinion, to a conclusion that the greenhouse issue should not outweigh all other factors relevant to the determination of whether or not to grant consent but must be taken into account in the court's overall assessment of the project.

What then are the other factors which the court must take into account in reaching this determination? Redbank pointed to the beneficial environmental effect of the project. It will use tailings as fuel, thereby avoiding the detrimental effects of tailings disposal in dams. It will produce lower emissions of SO2 and NOX in comparison to the coal‐fire power stations which it is likely to displace.

There are other beneficial effects as well. The project will reduce the amount of land sterilised by tailing dams. It will convert a waste product into a usable one. It will permit more efficient use of energy resources by recovering coal currently discarded in tailings. The project was comprehensively assessed by council. Government and other authorities were consulted and objections addressed. In taking all these matters into account, I have concluded that the development application should be approved.

In February 1997, Redbank applied to the New South Wales Land and Environment Court for a modification of the development consent in regard to the improvements to reduce CO2 emissions. National Power fully briefed Greenpeace on the modification and Greenpeace did not contest the application. The modification was granted as requested. With respect to this project, every reasonable environmental consideration that could have been taken into account, was taken into account.

The other issue I draw to the attention of the Senate, and particularly to my Greens colleagues, is that one of the four projects relates to Port Stephens. It is a sewerage project to clean up the ocean, which will otherwise be polluted by sewage emissions. That is one of the projects that may not go ahead as a consequence of the government's approach.

We are disappointed with the Greens' approach on these four development projects which we are seeking to ensure. They followed due process, they applied to the DAA, and they were granted approval. It is not up to the Treasurer to unilaterally gut the approval process, which is what he did and what he is asking us to approve retrospectively. I certainly do not think Greenpeace would have been thrilled if the Treasurer had announced that he was, in the national interest, determined to override the courts in respect of this Redbank project and introduce retrospective legislation so Greenpeace could not hear any part of the process, either through the New South Wales Land and Environment Court or the appeal before the Chief Justice. I certainly do not think the Greens would have been happy if the process had been gutted, as is effectively being proposed in respect of four of the projects that the amendments go to.

As I have said, on environmental grounds, Redbank is an innovative coal fired power station in the Hunter, using coal tailings; and it also has very important economic and employment consequences. It is the same with the other projects. I certainly believe they withstand any reasonable environmental test. I would not want to see the Port Stephens sewerage project not go ahead, for example.

That is the effect of the amendments we are considering. I do not know whether my contribution has changed the position of the two Green senators. I am sure they will indicate their position in the debate on these amendments. I would not seek to unduly delay us and so, except if there some extraordinary response, I will not be making any further contributions on the amendments before us.

TALK.START.PARA: —Not wanting to repeat what happened before, in the absence of anyone else standing, I have stood. In relation to the Commonwealth vehicles bills, this legislation is just another example of the blind ideological belief of this government in privatisation.

SPEECH.PARA: Whilst in the past I have been critical of the long‐term economic costs and the social and environmental costs of other privatisation decisions, this bill does not make any financial sense, particularly in the long term. Whilst the sale of DASFLEET has the immediate effect of reducing budget outlays, the ongoing costs will almost certainly be increased as a result of the new owner's charges, which will be greater because of the high interest charges that the new owner will incur, because no‐one can obtain finance as cheap as the long‐term government bond rate. In addition, the new owner of these vehicles will want to pass on some margin representing their profit on top of the borrowing costs.

I have it on good authority that, assuming that DASFLEET is worth approximately $300 million, operating costs could increase by $24 million per annum. In reality, what we are doing in this bill, in my opinion, is giving a subsidy to private industry. I do not see the rationale for it, except an ideological one. It is yet another example of short‐term economic benefits outweighing any longer term economic costs. The Greens will be opposing these bills.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Faulkner, Sen John

TALKER.NAME: Senator FAULKNER
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Opposition in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —The government, in presenting these bills, is simply maintaining the status quo of exemption from state and territory taxes and charges, including compulsory third‐party insurance applying to motor vehicles used by the Commonwealth.

SPEECH.PARA: Let me say from the outset, the Labor opposition will not oppose the passing of the legislation. We do not wish to be unnecessarily obstructionist. We accept that this legislation in no way pre‐empts the final decision on either the sale or the refinancing of DASFLEET. It just ensures that, whatever decision the government takes, it will be cost neutral. Nor will we be obstructing the legislation to actually prevent the sale or refinancing. But we cannot pass up this opportunity that is provided by this legislation to expose the government's hypocrisy and double standards on privatisation, competitive neutrality, Commonwealth‐state financial relations and taxation reform.

Let us get clear what this legislation provides for. Firstly, the legislation exempts from state and territory taxes the transfer of DASFLEET assets, including the motor vehicle fleet. It is standard practice to exempt certain privatisation transactions from stamp duty, but only when the stamp duty arises on the actual transfer refinancing, and only when the privatisations are of an equity nature—that is, shares. That is not what we are talking about here. The privatisation of DASFLEET is the sale of specific physical assets—a different category altogether. The stamp duty that any ordinary Australian would have to pay when they purchase a car or that any company operating a vehicle leasing business would have to pay on the vehicles they purchase will not have to be paid by the new owner of DASFLEET vehicles. What a bargain!

Secondly, the legislation establishes a motor vehicle register, exempting vehicles on the register from the need to be registered under a law of the state or territory or to have third‐party insurance. The Commonwealth currently operates several thousand vehicles registered under state and territory law. They are mostly vehicles provided under senior executive vehicle schemes. The Commonwealth currently pays registration fees. However, it does not currently pay stamp duty on the registration of such vehicles, due to its exemption from state and territory taxes.

BREAK.PARA: The government is arguing that this legislation will maintain this position by extending the exemption to the private owner of vehicles where those vehicles are leased to the Commonwealth for at least three months. However, the existing arrangements are being changed in one important respect—the vehicles will not be owned by the Commonwealth any more.

Thirdly, where the vehicle is leased to the Commonwealth for at least three months continuously, the leases will be exempt from state and territory taxes levied on leasing arrangements. Again, this is a new tax exemption which is being imposed by the Commonwealth. It is not the continuation of an existing arrangement.

Fourthly, the Commonwealth currently bears its own liability for third‐party insurance through the Commonwealth Motor Vehicles (Liability) Act 1959. The second bill extends the Commonwealth's liability to cover vehicles that are leased to the Commonwealth or a Commonwealth authority through an amendment to the 1959 legislation. It is worth noting that the measures in these bills will apply to vehicles leased to the Commonwealth by any company, not just the purchaser of DASFLEET.

The point I would like to make is that a critical feature of privatisation of public businesses is that they subsequently come fully within the tax net as opposed to their status when in public ownership. Currently, a business owned by the Commonwealth is exempt from such taxes because of the exemption from state and territory taxes which the Commonwealth enjoys. What is happening in the DASFLEET privatisation is that ownership is being transferred from the Commonwealth to the private sector. Accordingly, the ongoing exemption from state and territory registration charges and stamp duty on lease documents, which this legislation proposes, is completely inconsistent with the usual privatisation practice. The fact that the Commonwealth subsequently uses the service is not relevant in this sense.

The government claims that, without the legislation, the Commonwealth would incur costs in the first year of approximately $10 million in registration fees, stamp duty on registration and compulsory third‐party insurance. The present net value over 10 years is estimated at $45 million. Purchasers would be charged stamp duty on the transfer of assets, excluding vehicles, of approximately $2.75 million deducted from the sale price paid to the Commonwealth by purchasers. The new owner of the vehicles would be charged around $1.5 million per annum for stamp duty on leasing arrangements, which would be passed on to the Commonwealth through vehicle leasing charges.

If the government believed its own rhetoric about privatisation, this sale would probably not go ahead, because the costs this legislation seeks to eliminate are such as to make privatisation of DASFLEET too expensive for the government. You really have to wonder whether the current arrangements did not serve the government better. When this government privatises, it is not necessarily about good economics. It is purely about their ideological obsession with the diminishing role of government.
What about the government's supposed commitment to the principles of competitive neutrality? The Minister for Administrative Services (Mr Jull) on 20 August 1996 said:

The application of full competitive neutrality will mean that DAS businesses will face tax equivalent payments, debt guarantee fees and dividend payments even when they are competing for Commonwealth government contracts.
Perhaps the duty parliamentary secretary could explain to the Senate how these principles are being applied in this case.

What about the Treasurer's attempt to impose Commonwealth wholesale sales taxes on the state and local governments last year? Remember that huge stand‐off at the Premiers Conference. One would have thought that what is good for the goose is good for the gander, but not when it comes to this government.

We accept that this bill protects the interests of the Commonwealth taxpayers and, accordingly, we will not be opposing the bill. But I invite Senator Campbell to explain the incon sistencies to which I have drawn the Senate's attention.

I further request that perhaps Senator Campbell could provide information to the Senate about the views of the victims of this legislation—that is, the states and territories. The coalition continually claims that they respect the proper role for states and territories, and that they are more federalist in their approach than the supposedly centralist ALP. However, it is the coalition who imposed tax on other governments. It is the coalition that cut $1.5 billion out of general purpose funds—the discretionary funds of states and territories—not the Labor Party. It is the coalition that is cutting specific purpose payments to these other governments. And it is the coalition which seeks to provide a special exemption for the Commonwealth from state and territory taxes. At a time when these governments are closing hospital beds and cutting back vital services, we believe that it is incumbent on the government to explain why it is further reducing that revenue that would otherwise flow to the states.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kernot, Sen Cheryl

TALK.START.PARA: —The Democrats oppose these bills. We believe that the practice of the sale of public assets, in this case, of Dasfleet, and the consequence leasing back, actually ends up costing the Commonwealth government, and therefore the taxpayers, more in the long run. That is a really important point that is rarely made in this debate. We are always told, `Get rid of this asset. Lease it back, so you have still got it, and there will be cost efficiencies.'

SPEECH.PARA: We do not accept the ideological view that the private sector does everything better, or the view that government owned assets should have to compete on level playing fields with the private sector. I think you can argue that there are benefits to taxpayers from preference for public ownership. It is appropriate, for example, at the local government level, for vehicles that are not part of salary packages; it is appropriate for those vehicles to be used on that kind of business and to maintain a tax exemption. All of this nonsense about level playing fields and competition should not be applied universally, because it ends up costing taxpayers money, not saving it. That is the principle we want to talk about, and that is why we are opposing these bills.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Campbell, Sen Ian

TALK.START.PARA: —There are a couple of points that I feel obliged to respond to. The first is in relation to Senator Faulkner's very legitimate questions about what is good for the goose being good for the gander. In fact, that was the subject of an article I wrote on this very subject about two years ago in relation to competitive neutrality, a principle that clearly the Commonwealth supports.

SPEECH.PARA: The states and the territories, I am advised, are not victims of this scheme. They would otherwise have received a windfall gain, and I do not think it matters whether you are a centralist or a federalist as to whether you want to give the states a windfall gain. It is better to ensure that the tax position is fair and to ensure that, as a result of these changes, the states and the Commonwealth stay in the same position.

In response mostly to Senator Kernot's comment, I would say that the sale of Dasfleet cars was already the policy of the previous government. What this does is ensure that the risk will always pass with the sale of the cars, notably the residual risk of resale. With those comments, and in view of the time, I would like to—
Senator Kernot interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Clearly we will be in a position to do that, Senator Kernot. I would like to thank senators for their brief, concise and highly articulate contributions, and commend the bill to the house.

House of Representatives reasons for disagreeing to Senate amendments Nos. 2, 3, 4, 5, 6 and 7—

This Amendment requires the minister to present to both Houses of Parliament, for any proposed change in rates or cessation of bounties covered by this act, a cost-benefit analysis of relevant bounties, including assessments of the impact on employment, exports, investments, growth and international competitiveness.

Processes already exist whereby this type of information and analysis is available—for example, through reviews requested by the government from the Industry Commission and other review panels on specific industries and on broad industry policy directions.
The House of Representatives therefore opposes the proposed Amendment.

These Amendments remove the provision for early termination of the Book Bounty (on 30 June 1997) such that termination reverts to 31 December 1997 as provided for under the Bounty (Books) Act 1986. The early termination of the Bounty was announced by the government in the 1996‐97 budget as part of its strategy of fiscal consolidation.

While the book printing and publishing sectors have derived significant benefits from the bounty in the past, this has been within an environment of declining rates of assistance—for example, the bounty has declined from 20 per cent in 1987 to 4.5 per cent on 1 January 1997. Over this period, bountiable production has increased. Removal of the 4.5 per cent bounty six months ahead of time should not have significant adverse impacts on the printing and publishing sectors. Accordingly, the House of Representatives opposes Amendment Numbers 3, 4 and 5.

These amendments remove the provision for early termination of the Computer Bounty, on 30 June 1997, such that the termination date reverts to 31 December 2000 as provided for under the Bounty (Computers) Act 1984. The early termination of the Bounty was announced by the government in the 1996‐97 budget as part of its strategy of fiscal consolidation.

Significant savings accrue to the budget arising from the decision to terminate the Bounty early. The government has also initiated a major review of the information technology industry. The Information Industries Taskforce has been asked to advise on measures that will ensure that the information industries sector will be able to take advantage of emerging opportunities, including in the context of the early termination of the Computer Bounty.

Given that the bounty has been paid at a gradually declining rate, currently at 5 per cent, that its impact on achieving industry development objectives has declined in importance and that the government's priority is to undertake a more comprehensive review of future strategies for the information technology industry, the Computer Bounty should be terminated on 30 June 1997. The House of Representatives therefore opposes Amendment Numbers 6 and 7.

TALK.START.PARA: —The opposition sees this issue in this way. There is one bill which amends four bills which now provide bounties to four separate industries in Australia—the shipbuilding industry, the book manufacturing and publishing industry, the machine tools and robotics industry and the computer industry. The Senate in its wisdom, when this bill was before us last, supported the amendments that the government made to the shipbuilding industry—amendments the government had been forced to make in bilateral discussions with that industry. That meets our position to rectify the situation for that industry.

SPEECH.PARA: When this bill was before us last, the Senate supported the government's motion on machine tools and robotics, which enables that bounty to expire on Monday 30 June but without going back to the government's original position of 30 June 1996 and thus having to retrospectively claw back the amount of bounty paid to the manufacturers of machine tools and robotics in Australia. When this bill was before the Senate last, it insisted that the government's pre‐election promise that the computer bounty be maintained until the end of the century be the position, and the government rejected that. The Senate's view was to support that. Now the House, where the government has a majority, has said that it insists on the government's original position, which was to terminate the computer bounty from Monday.

The fourth bill relates to the book manufacturing and publishing industry. The Senate extended the book bounty to the end of the year. If the book bounty was not extended against the government's wishes then it would terminate on Monday too.

The point is that the government is saying to us now, `We will honour the deal that we have reached with the builders of fast catamaran ferries in Australia, accepting that if you insist that the computer industry should have the bounty we will not honour it.' The motion I foreshadowed I would move, if we go back to reporting progress to enable me to move it, would have the effect of dividing this one bill which amends those four bills I have referred to so that the amendments would appear for each bill separately. The Senate could then accept the government's position, as we have previously said we would, on ships, and that could be disposed of. The divided bill would just amend the shipping building bounty.

The Senate could then accept the government's view on machine tools and robotics and that bill could be amended. Then the Senate could debate the amendments to the computer bill and the book bill separately as freestanding amendments. I want to prevent the government from cross‐trading and holding the Senate up to blackmail by saying, `If you do what you believe in your wisdom you should do on computers, we will scuttle the deal with the ships.' That is the purpose of what I want to achieve. I hope that is relatively well explained.

It really is designed to make it more difficult for the government to scuttle the computer bounty if the Senate in its wisdom continues its position. Of course the government still could if it were pernicious. If the government said that the Senate has divided this bill, and there are now four separate bills and each one will be dealt with separately, and it insists on all the amendments and changes that it has made and the position, as the Senate had before, remains the same and the government does not have one bill in which it can cross‐trade but four separate bills, it can still lay them aside and say we are not going to proceed. The government has reached with the leaders of the shipbuilding industry a specific deal, which was outlined by the minister in this chamber last week and which is set out in Hansard because I had it inserted in Hansard by leave of the Senate in the last debate. The terms and conditions of that discrete deal with that industry are clear. In the terms and conditions of that deal with this industry there was no condition which said that if the Senate amends the computer bounty, the terms of this shipbuilding agreement are null and void.

I think the government is honour bound, irrespective of what fulminating it might undertake now, to observe the deal that it has done with the Australian shipbuilders—contracted between them in good faith; a contract by the shipbuilders with the government and by the government with the shipbuilders—without now for parliamentary tactical purposes putting a caveat on it that was never intended and would not apply: namely, that if in the case of the computer industry we want justice for them as well, the whole package with the shipbuilding industry fails.

When the government says to the Senate, `If you insist on your views, we will blackmail you, we will penalise you by damaging this industry,' I say to the government, `That's rubbish; I call your bluff.' I do not believe that is true. The reprehensible position put by the minister on behalf of the government is not a position that I think is credible. I just do not believe that the government could continue to act in that way. This is a bit of parliamentary sport; this is not the real world. The government, and this Senate, should support the shipbuilding package—it is not perfect, but it is about 99.9 per cent perfect—and the government should imple ment it.
