That leaves me to talk to the Senate about the other two bounties, which this Senate amended. The first of them is the books bounty. As I said last time in the debate over this bounty, this is an important industry for Australia. It is an area of comparative advantage in the Australian economy over other nations. That comparative advantage arises because we are an intelligent country. We have a high level of learning and literacy. We are able to write, design and present books that sell in the United States. Australian companies supply a number of the textbooks in the Californian education system, a number of the textbooks in the state of Florida's education system, a number of textbooks that are in circulation in India, in Malaysia and in other countries of the world. We export our intellectual capability in educational services by providing those books, and we do so and we win those contracts in the United States against the toughest competition in the world, and in Asia against strenuous competition from other nations to get the publishing rights.

This industry has been able to grow to that level because it had a bounty, and it was certain of when that bounty would expire. This legislation chops this bounty off, it disrupts the plans of the industry, it throws people in the major printing centres around Australia—but, most importantly, at Maryborough in Victoria—into disarray. It disrupts the advantage of the industry to be able to plan; it undercuts its ability to enter those foreign markets and maintain its position. That, taken together with the government cuts to the export market development grants scheme, on which this industry relies to get into foreign markets, is a massive blow against this industry.

The message from the House is not believable or credible. I cannot find one government member who in private will give it any credibility. It is a shrug of the shoulders and their saying, `Well, that's what we've got to say—but, well, you know, the implication is that we don't believe it.' Of course it is not believable, it is not credible. It suffers from the defect that it is not true. If it were true, it would be credible. The defect it has is that it is not true and it, therefore, is not credible.

This is not just an issue of the book industry. The Senate economics committee, when it considered the bounties for this industry, had evidence before it about the government's insistence on charging the full measure of tariff; it had evidence before it about the level of tariff imposed on imported paper which goes to the manufacture of books in Australia. A cross-party committee of Liberals, Nationals, Democrats and the Australian Labor Party agreed that that level of tariff for the publication of books in Australia, where it does not compete with any Australian manufacturers of paper, should be removed—and that was a unanimous position.

The government has declined to do so. Since we supply about 70 per cent of the paper needs for book manufacture in Australia, and import about 30 per cent, this government is imposing an extra surcharge on the cost of book manufacture in this country, while cutting out the bounty. This means that in the world this industry is vulnerable. It has been able to win against international competition, bearing these costs to industry assistance, cuts to industry assistance and the cost impost on having to pay a tariff for imported paper to go into their manufacture. This industry is being put deliberately at a commercial disadvantage.

For those reasons, we reject the reasons provided by the House of Representatives. We argue strongly for the fact that, in the case of the books bounty, the original position of the Senate should be retained. That is the view of the printing industry. That is the view of the paper industry. Tasmanian paper manufacturers have made that view clear. It is the view of this industry and its workers. To take the stand the government has taken is to take a stand against employment in Australia, interesting, highly skilled, important jobs in Australia—

TALK.START.PARA: —Jobs in Tasmania.

—jobs in Tasmania, and see this industry go offshore. If the government insists and its motion is carried, we will be standing on the dock at Australian ports waving goodbye to this industry as it goes offshore. The record already is that, since the announcement in the 1996-97 budget that this bounty was to be cut, there has been a slow trickle of book publishers putting more work offshore and handling less work in Australia. That will continue. It will become a flood. For those reasons, I oppose the book bounty.

SPEECH.PARA: I also want to say that we oppose the computer bounty. The value of the book bounty is about $5 million per annum—a small price to pay. The value of the computer bounty is about $140‐odd million. The reason the government insists on taking away the computer bounty is the amount of money. It is not the principle of the thing, it is not the industry purpose the bounty serves; it is simply a crass cost‐cutting measure in order to remove the bounty and save money for the government—or so it believes.

As we saw in evidence before the Senate committee, in the case of these industries no cost‐benefit analysis has been done to check the impact on employment, to check the impact on taxes paid out of company profits in this sector, or to check the impact on other costs the government has to shell out. The one industry sector that had done a survey on that was the book industry. That survey showed there is, in fact, a net deficit to the budget by cutting out the bounty because, when you consider that you put people on the dole, you lose income tax from workers engaged in the workplace, you lose tax on company profits and you lose a number of other taxes, the net impact on the budget bottom line is negative in the cutting out of these bounties.

In the case of the computer industry, it is even more so. As I said in this debate last week, the computer and telecommunications industry is now the biggest industry in the world. It is also the fastest growing and the most rapidly changing industry. Australia has a net trade deficit in the import of computer technology of $6 billion a year. By the end of this century that deficit will be $20 billion a year, even if the computer bounty is retained.

BREAK.PARA: No study has been made to see what the budgetary benefit is. The government says, `We simply want this money', but they have not done any study to see what the negative effects of taking this money away will be on the growth and development of this industry or on the yawning gap of our trade deficit, or what will be the impact on jobs and on its own budget bottom line.

TALK.START.PARA: —Because they can't; they can't do it.

—They won't do it. You are right: they can't do it. The government has said to us—the minister just said it a moment ago—`But we have the Goldsworthy report; we think this is an important industry, so we are looking at it'. What they are proposing to do is take $140 million out of the pockets of this industry, deal it a devastating blow, slam the stable door, let the horse bolt, and then say, `Let's conduct an examination to see what the impact is on the industry and work out how we grow the industry from here on.'

BREAK.PARA: For companies that have to plan in the long term in this, the fastest growing industry sector in the world, the most dynamically changing industry sector in the world, you remove their ability to plan for the future because you disrupt their planning at every stage. It is just an impossible position.

This is an industry in which there are a number of headline, household name players that are world companies, but it is also an industry in which there are thousands of small Australian companies, each of which attract the bounty and each of which are important in maintaining our competence in this important field of technology—and important for maintaining the skills of the Australian work force as well.

Let me conclude my remarks on the computer bounty by saying that the excuse of the government that the Goldsworthy task force will report is not a viable excuse as it will report after the event. It will be a survey of the wreckage and damage that has occurred, not a survey of what we can do to improve the competitiveness of this industry in the future. That is the first point.

The second point is this. At the election, what did this government say? It said it would keep this bounty to the end of the century, and it said that loudly and strongly to every computer manufacturer and to every manufacturer of component parts for information technology in this country. To every company that makes a washing machine, a car or a household appliance that has a smart chip in it, it said, `We will keep this bounty.' But what does this bill propose to do? After reconsideration, it proposes to chop it out from Monday. So the second point is the explicit breach of an election undertaking.

The third point relates to no consideration. The government says it needs the money. It has not considered the cost‐benefit analysis that taking this money will create in industry—the amount of unemployment, the inability to grow, the disruption to company planning or the strategic positioning of Australian companies against worldwide competition. It has not considered that. It is just a grab for the cash; it is not a consideration of industry needs.

There are other points, but I will conclude by saying that for those reasons the opposition, the Labor Party—and I want this to be clear—opposes the removal of those bounties. We believe the Senate, in its wisdom last time it considered these things, voted the right way, and we implore it to do so a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Murray, Sen Andrew

SPEECH.PARA: This is a government which prides itself on economic management. It considers itself the best—or the better—economic manager in the country. Its members also like to think of themselves in business terms. They often talk about things in business terms. But here we have a set of people which would be an extraordinary mix to have on any business board. You wonder how many of them have managed anything of moment. I think it was Ms Hanson who described—

TALK.START.PARA: —Geoff Prosser.

I think he does exceptionally well for a lawyer with a suburban practice as his background. Nevertheless, my concern is that we have a weak and inexperienced government when it comes to management.

SPEECH.PARA: You can hear that in the way it responds to well‐known practical international mechanisms that are used by the largest organisations and the most professional governments and companies in the world. The process of cost‐benefit analysis or of any analysis of an issue means weighing up what the effects of one action are on a set of another actions. This government, because it is weak, inexperienced, incompetent and a poor manager, has persistently failed to do that. It has failed, and we have asked it again and again for analysis. This government is not able to say to Australia and to industry, `The effect on investments, jobs, growth, et cetera is the following—'.

You respond by saying, `We cannot do a simple cost‐benefit analysis; it far too complex.' What do you think major companies do when they consider whether they should invest in some operation or not spend money on others? As a government, you do not understand how condemned and how damned you are in the eyes of the community and in the eyes of industry by those kinds of statements, because people think, `My goodness, what sort of people are managing this economy?'

So that is the first part of the problem: you simply do not understand; it is tragic but you do not understand that all the Senate is saying to you is, `If you want to save the money on the computer bounty, tell us why it benefits Australia more than it will cost Australia.' Let us go to the second problem. The second problem in the eyes of the world, and increasingly in the eyes of Australia, is that you are known as a government that does not honour its agreements and is not to be trusted—the Richard Nixons of Australia. The mining industry screamed at your breach of agreement on the DFR. They screamed—and I heard them during the hearing—that you had broken the agreement that you had made with them. We understand that you arrived in government and said, `The books are in a worse state than we thought' and you have to save money. We have sympathised with that; the Senate has supported most of your intentions to balance the books. But on this issue we regard the cost as greater than the benefit so we have put a simple proposition to you: go away, finish your Goldsworthy report and come back and show us the evidence and do the job.

Then we move to the question of blackmail. You never said to the shipbuilding people when you renegotiated the bounty, `This renegotiation is conditional on the computer bounty saving.' TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Murray, may I indicate to you that you must be careful in regard to the context in which you are using the word `blackmail'.

The income from those bonds can be directed into the standard of care which is needed for those centres that can attract higher bonds, if this provision is to be applied, to have a greater quality and range of aged care services.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Ellison continues to give us examples off the top of his head, whether he talks about railings on stairs, as he did yesterday, or driveways today.

—I have visited hostels and nursing homes, Senator Ellison, so I do have some understanding of them. You started to talk about driveways today. The point is that you belittle the issue. Let us understand what happened yesterday and what is happening today. Yesterday we put forward amendments, which the government opposed, particularly the proposal that was contained in our amendment here, which the government said was totally unnecessary. The proposal put forward was one which was clearly in line with all of the government's rhetoric on this bill. You have said from day one that there is a need to provide funds for capital improvement to improve the stock of nursing homes in this country. That has been the argument put forward all along by the government as to why this system of accommodation bonds was necessary and that the income that would be derived from accommodation bonds paid by residents of nursing homes would be directed to that end.

SPEECH.PARA: We then sought to ensure that that was reflected in the legislation; that it was put into the legislation in no uncertain terms so that it would be clear to providers that that was to happen. We did not want there to be opportunities for nursing home providers who did not feel that they needed to do too much in the way of capital improvement—even though that is clearly what the accommodation bond income was for, and such improvement could be undertaken—to see this as a windfall for their nursing home facility, their company, particularly if it is a for profit company, to utilise such income for purposes other than what it is primarily intended for. Of course that could quite easily be directed towards providing higher standards of care for some residents who pay an accommodation bond than for concessional residents.

Let us be frank about it: once you have a system like that and you rely upon the market to drive it—that is what you are doing; you are relying on the market to drive this system; there is no cap and there is no specified amount as to what the bond should be; rather, it is all a matter of negotiation and dependent on the real estate market—it does create opportunities for nursing home providers to find ways to utilise this income for other than what it is primarily intended. As long as that is legal, there will be providers who will endeavour to do it.

We went to the trouble of constructing an amendment. We all recall we had a bit of discussion to find the appropriate words to reflect in the act that principle that you have said all along underpinned the provision of accommodation bonds. The government did not support it, but the Democrats did and it was carried by the Senate. Today it went back to the other place. You have accepted the Senate's amendment, except in so far as you have added some words into paragraph 3, which are the words that you have read out.

BREAK.PARA: Whilst the government's amendment retains the broad principles that the opposition's amendment was based upon and that the Senate carried, it gives a clear indication to nursing homes providers out there—who may feel that they do not need to put any more of this income into capital improvement, but rather have a motivation to increase the income from the bonds they receive, to charge the highest possible bonds because they are private, profit‐making enterprises—that they can establish a two‐tier system of care.

We have been saying all along that this is one of the dangers of your legislation, and what the government has done today sends that message out: if you are a nursing home provider and you are in the business of making a profit, you can set the highest possible bond that you believe you can recoup in the market. If, in particular, you are a facility that is of more recent construction and therefore probably not needing as much capital improvement, you are going to have a great opportunity here to divert that income into providing different and higher standards of care than might otherwise be provided to concessional residents in that home or, indeed, in other parts of the industry.

This a real recipe for leaving the side door open for that to occur. That is why the opposition believes, as has been expressed in the house today and in here today, that you really are still trying to keep that door open and send the signal, notwithstanding what you say the basic principle is that underpins the accommodation bond system: `Don't worry. If you want to use it to promote better standards of care so you can attract more wealthy people to pay higher bonds and, therefore, increase the profit, then you are quite able to do so.'

The position of the opposition is that we still believe that the amendment that we put forward is the better wording. It clearly sends the message out to the industry that the accommodation bonds are to be used for the purposes that the government has said all along they should be used for. We have said that that should be reflected in the act. The Senate agreed with that yesterday.

We believe the original wording was better. Now the government has come back with this wording. My understanding is that it is likely to be supported by other parties in the Senate. We are very concerned about the future because of the words that you have now sought to include in our original amendment and the way you have changed it. It is going to be on the government's head when we find out in a year or two a diverging standard of care in nursing homes across the industry.

The amendment, nevertheless, still retains essentially the elements that the opposition was seeking to have included in the legislation. So whilst we are not happy with, and certainly disagree with, the proposals from the government, at least it is better than the bill as it was when this government first introduced it into the Senate.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would just like to indicate to the chamber that, in the interests of continued cooperation with the government, obviously I will commence in respect of the Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 3) 1997. SPEECH.PARA: The Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 3), as has been mentioned, is an omnibus tax bill covering a wide number of areas—many of which were announced in the budget. The major matters include superannuation, capital gains tax and other tax issues. In respect of the superannuation changes, the legislation proposes to change the taxation arrangements for superannuation by, firstly, granting an exemption from capital gains tax for up to $500,000 for small businesses which use the money for retirement purposes; secondly, allowing a rebate at the rate of 18 per cent for superannuation contributions made on behalf of low income earners—that is, under $10,800 per year or non-working spouse; and, thirdly, increasing the maximum employee age under which superannuation guarantee payments must be made by employers from 65 to 70 to be consistent with the rights of employees to continue to contribute to super funds until age 70.

Labor has strong concerns about the equity of the first of these two proposals and unequivocally supports the third. The Senate has referred these issues to the Senate Select Committee on Superannuation for examination. The committee has reported. We do not oppose these measures, but we will be moving some amendments.

My next area in respect of this legislation is the small business exemption. We have concerns about the half a million dollar exemption purpose proposal which relates to the fairness of this measure. We accept that for many people their small business has been the way that they have saved for their retirement. For some people, business cash flow needs have precluded the capacity to save regularly in a superannuation fund. In addition, prior to Labor's reform of what are known as the reasonable benefit limits, RBLs, there was a significant bias against small business in superannuation in some circumstances, especially where the businesses were not incorporated.

As usual, despite the rhetoric of the coalition, it was Labor that fixed the anomalies that confronted small business, not the coalition. Indeed, it was the current Prime Minister (Mr Howard), when he was the responsible minister, who presided over many of the unfair aspects of superannuation in the taxation system, which Labor reformed in its 13 years in office.

So there has been a problem historically. It is by no means clear whether significant further large concessions are justified. Tax, albeit at concessional rates, is payable on superannuation contributions, fund earnings and the final benefits of ordinary employees.

This bill proposes to completely exempt from tax a substantial capital gain—half a million dollars—on condition only of the age of the recipient and the funds being used for retirement purposes. This provides a very significant advantage in tax terms between small business people and the great bulk of the Australian community who are employees. There was some comment earlier today in the context of another debate that the average superannuation fund balance at the moment is $38,000. I think we have to contrast the position here with the government providing a significant concession of half a million dollars to small business in the event of rollover into superannuation, and the debate that occurred here earlier in relation to the government's approach to deeming the superannuation assets of persons who reach 55 if they are on a social security unemployment or disability pension. There does seem to be a significant contrast.

I would certainly submit to the Senate that that deeming provision—I have referred to it as a vicious measure, which is what it is; a vicious measure—stands in contrast to the way in which small business is to be treated. It provides a significant advantage in tax terms between small business people and the great bulk of the Australian community.

As I said earlier, $38,000 is the average amount in superannuation accounts. The tax advantage that is being conferred here to small business is 13 times the size of the average superannuation account balance which is proposed to be exempt from tax, whereas the much smaller sum has already faced taxation and will probably face further taxation when it is paid out.

We can post the question: why shouldn't equivalent taxation regimes apply to both employees and to small business? Why is it proposed that the rules will disproportionately favour one group of Australians over the other? Certainly I have not seen a cogent rationale from the government, other than purely political rhetoric. Again, that is in a similar vein to the sort of political rhetoric we dealt with yesterday in respect of the exemption of small business from unfair dismissal laws.

Another relevant fact to consider in assessing the merits of this proposal is that, by definition, this exemption only applies to those assets which are covered by the capital gains tax; that is, any asset acquired by a small business person prior to 20 September 1985 is exempt from capital gains tax anyway. So, we do not believe that it is correct to imply that the current law disproportionately discriminates against small business propri etors who have spent their life building a business. Any proceeds from the sale of a longstanding business will be exempt from capital gains tax. In addition, when Labor was in office we instituted a benefit for small business, namely, a 50 per cent exemption from capital gains tax on goodwill up to the value of $21 million, which currently applies under the current capital gains tax system.

Let me stress we have had an open mind on this issue. But we wish to ensure that where the government is presenting a fair measure—as, indeed, we did in respect of tax law No.1—we do not allow rorting by the top end of town which could become available to a small number of people and not available to the many. In saying that, I am certainly not suggesting that rorting should be available to the many; it should not be available to anyone. This concession must also be considered in the context of the capital gains tax rollover relief proposal which we have just dealt with. I assume we will be receiving a message very shortly.

These two measures—the measure we are discussing here and the capital gains tax rollover relief proposal which the Senate has dealt with and is awaiting a message from the House—are further significant relaxation of an important part of the tax system. Again, Labor is not opposed to clearing away unfair taxation hurdles or amending provisions which impact negatively on jobs or growth. But, that said, this—together with the measure in tax laws No. 1—will be a very significant change in the comprehensiveness of the tax base.

I would submit that the coalition has always opposed the fairest measures in our tax system, such as capital gains tax, and has, in the past, wished to repeal it. Contemporary community attitudes, we believe, would preclude full repeal of the measure. Consequently, Labor is wary of attempts to effectively repeal the measures for certain sections of the community via a backdoor means.

I would now like to make some comments in respect of the superannuation spouse rebate—the 18 per cent rebate for superannuation contributions made on behalf of a low income or non‐working spouse. Again, the Senate committee looked at this measure carefully. What is interesting about this measure, what is instructive about the focus of this measure, is that it assumes that people will have a spare $3,000 to contribute to their spouse's superannuation in situations where the spouse does not work or only works part time.

Indeed, we saw this approach illustrated in the savings rebate initiative recently announced in the budget. With respect to superannuation, it assumes that there is going to be a massive incentive created for persons to place money into superannuation accounts. In the case of superannuation, to obtain the massive incentive rebate of $450 you would have to place $3,000 in a superannuation account. Labor certainly does not believe that low and middle income earners have that level of spare cash on an annual basis in order to avail themselves of the $450 rebate.

The measure we are looking at here is the 18 per cent superannuation spouse rebate. In practice, this measure will really only benefit those relatively few people we regard as well off. It is not going to benefit middle and lower income Australians. When the Prime Minister talks about helping families he is talking about assisting those families with plenty of money and plenty of investment options. I would submit to the Senate that he is not interested in helping the battlers who really need and would materially benefit from being able to save more.

The next measure I would like to make some comments on concerns capital gains tax. I would like to briefly mention a number of the changes to the CGT arrangements. The changes involve clarifying the rules about CGT on inherited property, including increasing the tax‐free period to dispose of the house from one year to two and reducing the record keeping requirements presently applicable, and enacting anti-avoidance rules covering manipulation of company liquidations and the elimination of anomalies in the loss provisions, both capital and revenue. These measures are reasonable and are not opposed by Labor.

The amendments recognise that anomalies can arise where a principal residence is inherited and subsequently disposed of and the consequent need for a more flexible regime covering these types of transactions. The need for the anti-avoidance provisions shows precisely why Labor is concerned about the exemption for retirement purposes that I discussed previously. Aggressive tax planning is a fact of life and constant vigilance is needed to keep the tax base sound. Labor supports the government's measures to tighten the capital gains net to address these loss and liquidation problems. Whilst Labor is committed to closing down these inadvertent holes in the tax system which allow the smart few to benefit at the cost of many, we are naturally equally concerned that gaping holes are not deliberately inserted in the tax net.

I will now refer to a number of other matters in this legislation. The bill also contains supposed anti-avoidance amendments under the research and development provisions which seek to amend the partnership provisions to ensure companies in partnership cannot effectively continue syndicate‐like operations which the government cancelled from July 1996.

The bill also provides for the disallowance of deductions for syndicates where the syndicate has been granted an extension but has breached a condition of that extension. Labor does not support the R&D changes which have necessitated the proposals in this bill. They are bad for jobs, growth and innovation. The amendments are necessary to fix anomalies in legislation accepted by the Treasurer (Mr Costello) last year and which was known at the time to be flawed. My colleague Senator Cook will make some remarks with respect to the R&D issue.

Also in this legislation payments received under the firearms surrender arrangements are to be confirmed as tax exempt for recipients other than gun dealers. I have Senator Bob Collins sitting next to me during my speech in this debate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kernot, Sen Cheryl

TALK.START.PARA: —The Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 3) deals with a number of tax matters, most of which are not contentious, and I intend speaking only on a limited number of them. The bill seeks to extend the capital gains tax rollover relief to retirement, allowing up to $500,000 of net capital gains to be rolled into superannuation when a small business person leaves the work force, and any rollover amount included in superannuation by the person will be counted towards the person's reasonable benefit.

SPEECH.PARA: The Senate Select Committee on Superannuation requested the government to provide modelling on whether this measure would raise retirement savings or not and the government has failed so far to provide that evidence. The argument for concessional tax treatment of retirement savings is to increase retirement savings. As the OECD correctly points out, a tax incentive for saving should only be approved if the increase in savings exceeds the cost of taxation. Because the government has not provided the modelling, we do not know with respect to this particular case.

This measure will cost $45 million a year by 1999‐2000 but will it raise retirement savings by a greater amount? We just do not know the answer to that question. The Democrats concede that many small business people do use their business as a retirement savings vehicle. Tax concessions need to be restructured, however, to increase retirement savings—we should not just hand out tax concessions willy‐nilly for people doing what they would have done anyway. The Democrats would support a well‐targeted tax incentive for small business people to save more for retirement but the question, as I say, is whether this incentive is well targeted or not.

This concession will exempt completely from capital gains tax the first $500,000 of net capital gains if that is used for retirement savings. The argument that small business people do not receive any concessions if they save through the family business is not quite correct. For a start, capital gains tax is fully indexed for inflation, published in Treasury's annual tax expenditure statement. PAYE taxpayers do not have the benefit of such indexations on their gross salaries or on their non‐superannuation savings.

Second, many taxpayers are able to use the structure of their family business, especially trusts and company structures, to tax plan their overall taxable income downwards. Many deductions which are not available to PAYE taxpayers are available to business taxpayers. So, overall, they often end up paying a lot less tax over their lifetimes than PAYE taxpayers, and the final value of the business includes many tax advantages.

The amount of $500,000 of capital gains is an awful lot of capital gains, because to get $500,000 of capital gains indexed for inflation with all the cost base adjustments that are available you are talking about an asset with a value of $1 million to $3 million. That is how much they will have available to them for retirement income. We have to ask about the comparisons made with benefits available to other taxpayers and the kinds of tax concessions which are already there for these people to save for their retirement. The Labor Party has proposed reducing the value of the concession to $250,000. Again, that is a lot of capital gains, probably reflecting a business with a value of up to $2 million. But we think the move by Labor is a step in the right direction.

The bill also deals with prospectors' mining rights and corrects some unintended aspects of amendments which were moved last year in the Senate by my colleague Senator Murray. We will be supporting those amendments. I understand that the Labor Party is also moving to introduce a five‐year sunset clause on these provisions, an amendment with which we also have some sympathy.

The third measure I will mention briefly is the proposed fringe benefits tax incentive for remote area housing for primary producers—which is, in fact, a $20 million gift to the National Party. At present, remote area housing enjoys an exemption from FBT only to the value of 50 per cent of the benefit. This exemption seeks to extend that to 100 per cent, but only for on‐farm accommodation.

What about all the other workers in remote areas subject to fringe benefits tax: state public servants, teachers, nurses, police? These people all still only enjoy a 50 per cent benefit, even though they are usually compulsorily transferred to remote areas. Bank employees, rail employees, mining employees: their employers still pay 50 per cent fringe benefits tax. When we have a minister here once more to answer questions on this, I would ask: why does this government care more about farming workers, and why is it prepared to act in a slightly discriminatory way against non-farming workers?

The fourth measure I wish to mention is the increase in the age limit for superannuation contributions. The Democrats support this. We have long campaigned to remove age discrimination in employment at both ends, the junior and the senior. This measure will remove discrimination against workers aged between 65 and 70 who want to keep working. These amendments will ensure that they get their full superannuation entitlements as a worker.

The fifth measure I wish to mention briefly is the R&D tax concession for partnerships. This amendment follows on from a successful Democrat amendment to the government's bill to close down the R&D tax concession for syndicates to exclude partnerships. Although the government failed to substantiate its claim that syndication was heavily rorted, it did establish, in our view, a case that syndication may not have been the most appropriate or cost‐effective method of promoting research and development.

This, combined with the fact that the government introduced the Start program for research and development as a replacement, and introduced transitional arrangements to cater for applications already in the pipeline, was the reason for the Democrats' support. This bill gives full effect to the Senate's December amendment, and we expect to support it.

The final matter I wish to address is the proposed rebate for superannuation contribu tions made on behalf of a low income or non-working spouse. This measure proposes a tax rebate of up to 18 per cent for the first $3,000 of contributions. I seek leave to continue my remarks later.

TALK.START.PARA: —The subject of my speech will, I guess, soon return to the front pages of the newspapers where, until just recently, it occupied a prominent position almost every day of the week. I am of course referring to the native title debate and, more specifically, to the exposure draft of the amendments to the legislation which were released earlier today. These amendments will be introduced into the other place early in the next parliamentary session and are likely to be debated in this chamber later in the year.

SPEECH.PARA: As a member of the parliamentary Joint Committee on Native Title, I look forward to taking part in the community consultations on the legislation which are also scheduled for the spring session. A few weeks ago, again as a member of the committee, I was privileged to visit a number of islands in the Torres Strait, including the island of Mer, the home and final resting place of Eddie Mabo whose name has been popularly attached to the legislation.

Over the past two weeks there have been extensive briefings on the draft legislation with the backbench committee, pastoralists, miners, resource development agencies, Aboriginal groups and, of course, other interested parties. The exposure draft of amendments released today represents a significant step in the delivery of an election promise to fix the extensive problems that exist with the current Native Title Act.

It is five years since the original Mabo judgment and three years since the Native Title Act was passed. Even the Australian Labor Party has agreed that the legislation requires amendment, and in fact today's exposure draft contains a number of amendments which were originally presented to the parliament by the previous government. Everybody who has had contact with the present legislation agrees that it requires amendment—even the lawyers, who have arguably been the group that has benefited most from this act.

The High Court's discovery in late 1992 that native title was a valid and recognisable form of land title, and that generations of eminent lawyers and jurists had apparently overlooked that it had been sleeping beneath us for 200 years, threw into turmoil what had been an established form and settled system of land tenure and property law. It was an earth‐shattering discovery which has had profound effects around this nation.

However, while the Native Title Act has proven to be a financial bonanza for lawyers, it has not done much for the Aborigines and, I might say, Madam Deputy President, it has done very little for the residents of the island of Mer who told us of the confusion and disappointment that, since native title had been discovered on their island, they had actually waited for something to substantially change, but of course it had not because it simply confirmed what they had believed all along.

BREAK.PARA: However, today on the Australian mainland not one square inch has been found by law to exist anywhere in Australia, although one agreement was recently struck for a development in northern New South Wales where compensation paid for alleged—but not established—extinguishment was 50 per cent above the market value of the freehold land.

Since the Native Title Tribunal has been established, literally millions and millions of dollars have been spent on this very expensive bureaucratic structure. So far, all that really has been created is an administrative and legal nightmare. The latest tribunal annual report reveals that there are 18 tribunal members, 160 staff and registry officers in six capital cities around Australia. More importantly, it has before it negotiation and mediation of more than 450 land claims around this country.

The total cost of this cumbersome bureaucracy is $20 million a year, and staff costs increased from about $2.5 million in 1994‐95 to more than $6.3 million in the following year. At the same time, travel for these staff almost doubled in the course of one year to more than $1.2 million. And still not an inch of native title has yet been legally found to exist. Surely this is a well‐established case that something has to change.

So the 10‐point plan which is embodied in the draft legislation that has been released by the government today is absolutely crucial in unravelling this costly and quite unworkable mess. In particular, the proposed legislation seeks to overcome the uncertainty in relation to pastoral leases caused by the operation of the existing provisions of the Native Title Act in conjunction with the very complex Wik decision.

The draft legislation released today is designed to provide legal validity for acts carried out between the commencement of the Native Title Act in January 1994 and the Wik decision on the assumption that pastoral leases and other tenures that were existing at the time extinguished native title. The new legislation will provide certainty to pastoralists that they can continue to carry on their primary production activities. It provides respect for native title, preserving the principles of native title as established in the Mabo case, and allows the claims to proceed. It provides confirmation of the common law relating to native title and, in particular, that it has been extinguished by current and historical freehold residential leases, commercial leases, and those agricultural and pastoral leases providing exclusive possession.

It provides that impediments to the development of municipal services in towns and cities should be minimised and that government powers to manage and regulate water should be put beyond doubt. It provides workability through removing impediments to development; builds on the government's proposed amendments to improve the processes of the Native Title Act 1993, and, importantly, it provides devolution to the states and territories in particular to allow alternative state and territory processes for granting mining titles on pastoral lease land. It offers a speedy and sustainable resolution of concerns and uncertainty, and, very importantly, the new legislation enables the right to renew mining leases without triggering the right to negotiate.

Native title is crucial in my own state of South Australia. A number of properties in our state presently have overlapping claims from different Aboriginal groups. Overall, while there are just over 16,000 Aborigines in South Australia, about 65 per cent of the state is under claim—much of it in the newly discovered resource‐rich Gawler Craton in the north.

The legislation package released today does not—I repeat `not'—abolish native title. It retains and respects the concept of native title and primarily proposes changes to the administrative regime created by the Native Title Act to administer native title claims. The package will address much of the dismay and confusion that has greeted the Wik decision, particularly by members of the resource and pastoral industries all over this country.

I must say how disappointed I was just yesterday to see one of the Aboriginal leaders move so quickly to denigrate the government's attempts to restore equity and fairness to this act. I do hope we can look forward to a more constructive approach as the legislation is debated in this place and as the statutory committee undertakes its consultations around this country. This issue is too important to approach on a partisan basis. It has to be approached in a way that will bring this country together to end the division and the unfairness and to restore fairness and equity to all of those affected by it.

TALK.START.PARA: —This year marks the jubilee of Australia's National Antarctic Research Expeditions. The jubilee year commemorates 50 years of Australia's involvement in the Antarctic region. It began with the first ANARE voyage in 1947 to establish the station at the isolated Southern Ocean outpost of Heard Island. A few months later, Macquarie Island station was established. Australia established Mawson, the first of its three stations on continental Antarctica, in 1954.

SPEECH.PARA: Last Saturday night, I had the honour and privilege, in my capacity as parliamentary secretary with responsibility for the Antarctic, to attend the jubilee midwinter dinner in Hobart at which the Minister for the Environment, Senator Robert Hill, delivered the principal address. The previous night, I was privileged as well to attend the Melbourne ANARE Club's annual dinner, which was their special one this year because it was the jubilee celebration.

On Saturday night, while we were celebrating in Hobart, jubilee celebrations were also being held at midwinter dinners in Australia's Antarctic bases at Mawson, Davis, Casey and Macquarie Island. As well, centres throughout Australia that have ANARE clubs—that is, clubs of previous ANARE expeditioners—will be celebrating the jubilee during this year.

At Hobart we had the traditional calling of the years where, starting with 1997, each set of winterers and summerers stood when their year was called. It was pleasing to note that in both Hobart and Melbourne, in each case with an exception of one year, there were representatives from each of Australia's expeditions to the Antarctic in each of the years. It was very pleasing to have at both functions Dr Phillip Law, the first director of Australia's Antarctic Division, and a well‐known and well‐respected Antarctic explorer and expedition leader. Dr Law is now getting on in years but is still as sharp and as bright and as keen on the Antarctic as he has ever been.

ANARE is the men and women who have travelled to the Antarctic and the sub‐Antarctic with Australian government expeditions since 1947. From the very early times of ANARE's history the expeditioners have endured winters at Australian stations, and they have had to be very special people. They have kept the stations functioning and programs operating through the darkness of winter, cut off completely from the outside world.

Australia is now unquestionably an international leader in Antarctic affairs. As a result of our presence in the Antarctic, Australia has gained considerable international recognition and respect, has made significant contributions to Antarctic scientific research and has maintained a standard of operations that other international Antarctic programs measure themselves against. Australia's achievements are a direct result of the professionalism, courage, determination and commitment of our expeditioners. It is also probably significant that, in this jubilee year as well, the AAP Mawson's Hut Foundation is starting work on the restoration and preservation of Mawson's original huts on the Antarctic continent constructed during his epic 1911‐1914 expedition.

In proposing the toast to ANARE at the Hobart dinner, I drew attention to the fact that in celebrating ANARE we should recognise not just the expeditioners who go to the Antarctic but many other people. We acknowledge the partners and families of the expeditioners whose contribution to Australia's program is measured in the months, and sometimes years, spent at home without partners, fathers and mothers. Indeed, we as a nation owe our thanks to those who remain behind.

As well, our expeditions would not be possible without the tremendous support given by the Australian Antarctic Division in Hobart, particularly by the current director, Mr Rex Moncur, and his staff, who have put so much personal effort, often well beyond the call of duty, into supporting the expedition members and their programs.

As well, we need to recognise and thank all those semi-official and private groups and individuals who in various ways have supported the ANARE cause over the years, again often well beyond the call of duty. The Saturday night dinner was sponsored by two of our better supporters, Apple Computers Australia and the Marine Board of Hobart. We are indeed indebted to them.

In this category I should also mention Mr Tim Bowden, the very well‐known broadcaster and commentator who was commissioned by the Australian government to write the history of Australia's Antarctic expeditions in a book called The Silence Calling, which I had the honour of launching at the National Press Club earlier in June. Mr Bowden has become a major publicist for Australia's efforts in the Antarctic, and in addition to his many other considerable attributes he is now well regarded as one of Australia's most significant Antarctic historians.

Finally we have to acknowledge the way that other national and international groups affiliated in some way with the Australian program over the years have cooperated with us. Our program does not operate alone in the Antarctic and, as we have learned over the years, there are many instances of support for other national programs for ships in trouble or for sick or injured expeditioners and the like. Through cooperation with other Antarctic nations in the various Antarctic forums we have received considerable benefit and we, of course, support them as they support us.

The men and women of the Australian National Antarctic Research Expeditions have done Australia proud by their efforts over the past 50 years. The government and the people of Australia are in return very proud of them and the work they have done.

I wish to comment today on the future of the textile, clothing and footwear industry in Australia and concerns that have been expressed about the forthcoming review of tariff protection for this industry sector in light of the Productivity Commission report due to be published next Monday.

Of course the TCF industry is, in reality three separate industries, covering a wide range of manufacturing industries involving the conversion of raw materials into consumer goods as diverse as footwear, carpets, towels and tarpaulins.

PARA.TAB: The industry is made up of many small to medium businesses in metropolitan and regional centres throughout Australia.
A significant feature of these businesses is that most are Australian owned and are often located in regional areas that offers local employment.

The industry is also a major exporter. In 1995‐96, the industry exported $2.7 billion worth of goods, greater than that of the automotive industry at $2.2 billion and computers and office machinery at $1.9 billion.

SPEECH.PARA: The industry employs
nearly 100,000 people, many of whom are from non‐English speaking backgrounds.

PARA.TAB: many of whom are women.
My state, in NSW 32,412 people are employed in the TCF industry, which is 34.7 per cent of the national total.
In addition the TCF industry employs an estimated 30,000 to 300,000 outworkers, workers performing work away from the business that has commissioned it, usually in the fashion garment industry.

SPEECH.PARA: Unfortunately some outworkers are employed on low wages, under shameful conditions.

The peak industry body the Council of Textile and Fashion Industries of Australia (TFIA) are working towards the implementation of a national strategy to stamp out exploitation of labour in Australia and to support similar policies within Australia's trading partners. Their efforts are commendable.

The TFIA and other relevant representative bodies are developing a Code of Conduct which will formally recognise remuneration standards and basic rights of outworkers faced with an unsatisfactory work environment.
With its huge turnover, export presence and capacity to employ Australians the government recognises the enormous impact trade in TCF goods has on the economy.

As the Productivity Commission is due to report on the TCF industry early next week, the question is whether the tariff protections scheduled to fall in accordance with the Asia Pacific Economic Co‐operation forum's free trade targets will be maintained, or whether the TCF industry, as with the automotive industry, can justify a pause in tariff reductions.
To address these questions, it is worth recounting a few historical facts underlying recent tariff reform in the TCF industry.

In the late 1980s parts of the industry received protection equal to tariff rates in excess of 130 per cent. In 1993, the Labor government's industry statement put in place a tariff reduction program which is scheduled to carry through the year 2000. At that time, the maximum TCF tariff will be 25 per cent on apparel and certain finished textiles.

The TCF industry flourished in Australia until the early 1970s. In 1974, the Labor government imposed a 25 per cent tariff cut at a time when wages had exploded. The subsequent currency revaluation had a drastic effect on competitiveness in the industry.

This in turn induced a flood of imports and the industry contracted. It is estimated that between 1972‐73 and 1977‐78 approximately 1,300 (32 per cent) of factories closed and 50,000 (30 per cent) of employees found themselves without a job.

In 1989 Labor instituted a TCF plan, designed to run until 1995, a feature of which was the removal of the quota system. In 1991, however, Labor revisited its plan, opting to accelerate the rate of protection reduction and to extend the plan beyond 1995.

The move to lower tariff protection coincided with a severe downturn in demand and cemented further rises in imports and job losses. Between 1987‐88 and 1993‐94, factory employment fell by 32 per cent, overall employment fell by 20 per cent and manufacturing output fell by 24 per cent.
While the tariff rate was systematically reduced, our balance of trade in TCF goods declined. Between 1990‐91 and 1995‐96, the trade deficit in TFC goods increased by almost $400 million.
As with other manufacturing industries, these policy decisions also oversaw the loss of jobs. Between 1984 and 1996, industry employment fell from over 123,000 to just 102,700.
It was against that background, that in 1996, the government undertook to review the current industry assistance arrangements, with a reference to the Productivity Commission.

While no doubt the usual arguments will be made that cutting tariffs will make firms more efficient, productive and make jobs more secure and benefit consumers in the long run, those in the industry argue for more measured progress towards trade liberalisation.

Not unreasonably, industry advocates point to efforts already being made to restructure and increase exports. Over the last 10 years the industry increased its exports from around $200 million of its turnover to over $1 billion.

One of the most frequent claims made in protection debates is that it is not a level playing field—that many countries have implemented specific trade barriers aimed at Australian products attempting to compete in their markets and that our tariff barriers should not fall unless our trading partners reduce their own barriers to approximately the same extent.

While the move to free trade is to be encouraged it is argued that Australia should not keep to the timetable in isolation—that unilateral tariff disarmament is a recipe for disaster. While that may be, the announcement of New Zealand's commitment to tariff reduction in accordance with APEC's timetable is a brave move away from `reciprocity'.
The future of the Import Credit Scheme, resourced until the year 2000 is also a cause of concern in the industry.
While it has undoubtedly provided many benefits to the TCF sector it is much more difficult to assess the net economic impact of this form of industry assistance.

The government recognises however that securing the future of the TCF industry is important and that there are many parties potentially affected by changes. There is however need for reform to ensure that the industry reaches its full potential.l
The TFIA has identified three levels of international barriers

PARA.TAB: formal barriers, tariffs, quotas and taxes
hidden barriers including delays at customs and other imposts—costs and add on charges for value added products; and
trading alliances and regional trading blocs

SPEECH.PARA: It will be important for the future of the TCF industry that our trade liberalisation policy does not disqualify or disadvantage Australia as a competitor in other markets.
It is in the national interest to provide a stable policy environment in which TCF industries can undertake major investment decisions with confidence.

PARA.TAB: The strong growth in import penetration over recent years, the actions of competitor countries, and most importantly, the progress of the TCF industry towards developing a global niche for itself are factors which the government will need to weigh carefully in the balance.

TALK.START.PARA: —Those who do not learn from the mistakes of the past are doomed to repeat them. I wish to speak on the matter of salinity and rural sustainability in Western Australia. In particular, I want to address the new Western Australian state government initiative known as the salinity action plan which was launched just prior to the recent Western Australian state election. The plan is being held up by the state government as the blueprint for reversing the serious decline in agricultural lands and waters in Western Australia resulting from increasing salinisation. According to the government, the salinity plan will involve the expenditure of a total of $3 billion over the next 30 years.

SPEECH.PARA: I will state at the outset that much of the plan, at least in terms of its stated objectives, is commendable and necessary. Much genuine concern has gone into preparing the plan. Some of the hoped for outcomes, if achieved, will be very beneficial to the Western Australian community and environment. However, I do want to make some criticisms of the plan and the thinking that underlies it, because of my profound concern that the plan is at risk of turning out to be yet another chapter in a long history of ill-considered, headline grab bing initiatives that end up being not just hollow but fundamentally counterproductive.

My concerns can be summed up by the old adage that those who do not learn from the mistakes of the past are doomed to repeat them. It is well understood that Western Australia's agricultural region is in the midst of a major sustainability crisis. It must be stressed that salinisation is just one symptom of this sustainability crisis. According to various reports, Western Australia has over 70 per cent of Australia's dry land salinity.

An estimated 1.8 million hectares of farmland are already salt affected, and this amounts to 10 per cent of the region's cleared farmland. It is believed that this figure could increase by 300 per cent to 6.1 million hectares in future decades. The underlying cause of salinisation is the clearing of the original deep‐rooted perennial native vegetation and its replacement by shallow‐rooted annual pasture species. Because of the removal of the original vegetation, water usage patterns and watertable dynamics have been radically altered, resulting in rising ground water levels.

As the ground water rises it brings to the surface salt deposits that exist naturally in the soils of the region. This salt then concentrates on or near the soil surface, killing vegetation and rendering large areas virtually unusable. The effects of increasing salinisation are felt throughout the south‐west, with creeks, rivers, lakes and wetlands all becoming saline. It is estimated that 18 million hectares of land in the south‐west have been cleared of their native vegetation, primarily for agricultural production, out of a total of 25 million hectares. That is 72 per cent. This in itself is an ecological disaster, aside from its consequences in terms of salinisation and other chronic problems.

As mentioned previously, salinisation itself is just one of a number of symptoms of unsustainable land management. The rural sustainability crisis manifests itself in many ways, including an escalating rate of loss of biodiversity, a loss of land available for agricultural production, a reactive increase to the use of chemicals and fertilisers, a loss of social and economic infrastructure, and a loss of community confidence in the efficacy of farming.

Action to address salinity needs to be undertaken within the context of an overall understanding of the interrelated problems confronting our rural environment, economy and communities. If one is to believe all the pre‐state election rhetoric, WA is poised on the edge of an unprecedented, coordinated whole of government campaign to reverse the effects of decades of mismanagement of our rural lands and waterways.

The salinity action plan campaign goes under the telling subtitle of `the war on salt'. This type of macho rhetoric is not far removed from the earlier rhetoric of `the battle against the bush', under which banner millions of hectares of native vegetation were removed from the agricultural region in the first place. It betrays a mind‐set that is not open, consultative, considered and seeking to make peace with the land we all call home. To a large extent the war on salt campaign is predicated on the allocation of substantial amounts of ongoing funding from the Commonwealth through the Natural Heritage Trust Fund.

The Senate has exposed many fundamental flaws in the setting up and operation of the Natural Heritage Trust and we appear to have equivalent flaws with the way the salinity action plan is being set up. We see a lack of transparency, a lack of openness and a lack of accountability. Most of all we begin to see deceit about action, money and intent with this state election promise. As with the trust, the salinity action plan has not been put out for public comment. It is a plan produced by a small number of senior bureaucrats and ministers, each with their own agendas. As with the trust, the salinity plan is controlled by a small group of ministers.

Out of a claimed total annual investment of $100 million in the salinity action plan, the WA government is proposing to invest just $57 million, and much of this is to be reallocated from existing government programs. In 1997‐98 the state government is allocating only $5 million of new money to the plan. In other words, we have a deafening announcement of a $3 billion flagship salinity action plan, and in its first year of operation the government allocates a mere $5 million of real new money. Is that some kind of joke?

The state government is also asking for $30 million per year from the Natural Heritage Trust Fund. It is apparent that some, if not all, of the $30 million is being requested essentially to fund farm forestry programs. While there are definite benefits in promoting farm forestry, and it needs to be implemented extensively, this funding does need careful scrutiny to ensure it meets the objectives of the trust. Also under the plan, the notorious WA Department of Conservation and Land Management, which I have previously described to you as Genghis CALM, is to reschedule its debt repayments in order to fund a largely experimental $18 million per year investment in commercial pine plantations in the drier areas of the agricultural region.

We thus see government agencies, which are supposed to be concerned with nature conservation, becoming increasingly entrepreneurial and using their limited budgets in questionable ways. We are alarmed at the potential for fundamental requirements, such as ecological sustainability and the protection of biodiversity, being overlooked in favour of thinly veiled commercial crops and commercial enterprises. Money to set up commercial farm forestry enterprises, or to encourage other commercial crops, notwithstanding the positive environmental and economic benefits, should not be coming from what is effectively the nation's only real source of environment and nature conservation funding, limited as it is.

We thus see with the salinity action plan a further mirroring of the budgetary contortions of the Natural Heritage Trust Fund in that money from this plan will be transferred from, or be at the expense of, other important core environmental programs within the state government's or other governments' environmental programs. Under this deceitful process, overall environmental funding is actually being reduced and narrowed in its focus. Siphoning off relatively large sums of money from the whole environment budget and spending them not even on the overall integrated rural sustainability plan but on an even narrower salinity management plan is simply unacceptable.

To summarise, the salinity action plan is shaping up as being seriously flawed in five key ways: firstly, its narrow focus on the symptoms—that is, salinity—instead of a broad approach based on rural ecologically sustainable development; secondly, a lack of community consultation; thirdly, dubious and difficult to follow funding arrangements; fourthly, it is being driven too strongly by a narrow short-term commercial agenda; and fifthly, the lack of attention to biodiversity conservation—for example, the plan does not involve an end to land clearing, which still continues to this very day.

As a sign of just how narrow and superficial this salinity action plan threatens to be, the state government has just axed a landmark committee and buried the report from that committee that makes recommendations for significant comprehensive reform of natural resources management in WA. That committee was the natural resources management task force.

It is most important to note that the way the government is proceeding at the moment risks repeating all of the mistakes of the past. For over 70 years, governments were warned about the serious adverse effects of massive land clearing in the south-west. For decades, scientists, conservationists, some agriculturalists and others were criticised or ignored by successive governments when calling for a slowing down or halting of the expansion of clear land farming into increasingly marginal lands.

Now with this new government initiative, the concerns and warnings from scientists, conservationists and the wider community are once again being ignored or marginalised. The government is not listening to calls for community consultation on the plan. The `we know best' attitude that has brought rural WA to its knees is still alive and well.

The Democrats, state and federal, will be keeping a very close watch on the way this salinity action plan unfolds because we do not want to be party to a repetition of the mistakes of the past. We urge both govern ments, state and federal, to be as proactive as they can to make sure that the salinity action plan really does deliver its promise.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Health and Family Services has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) (a)-(e) The Office of the Ombudsman, following complaints received, wrote to the Department of Health and Family Services in August 1996. There followed an exchange of correspondence between the Department of Health and Family Services and the Office of the Ombudsman. On 23 April 1997 two officers from the Department of Health and Family Services met with the Melbourne office of the Ombudsman. At that meeting, the Departmental officers also made arrangements for the visit of an officer from the Ombudsman's office to the Department of Health and Family Services on 28-29 April 1997.
The Ombudsman's office has not, as yet, provided a report to the Department of Health and Family Services, and the Minister cannot pre-empt any findings of the Ombudsman.

(4) The incidence of CJD remains extremely rare As each year passes, more recipients are reaching the stage where the risk of contracting CJD is similar to that of the general population.

CJD is a rare disease occurring at the rate (for all types of CID) of one in a million in the general population per annum. The incubation period for iatrogenic CJD in Australia is in a range of 14 to 16—¢ years. The Australian Human Pituitary hormone Program (AHPHP) ceased in 1985 AHPHP recipients confirmed with CID were treated early (1973-78) in the program. There has not been a death of an AHPHP recipient from CJD since 1991

(5) Advice has been received that the CJD registry in Melbourne is aware of small number of cases where blood or tissue donation occurred and the donors subsequently died of CJD). There is no record of organ donation.

(6)(a)-(c) Post-mortem confirmation is not essential for the Commonwealth's offer to operate. While definitive diagnosis of the presence of CreutzfeldtJakob disease is confirmed by autopsy there are nevertheless clear clinical symptoms of CJD, including dementia, sudden myoclonic muscular jerks and unusual brainwave patterns as indicated by electroencephalograph (EEG). Given the knowledge of a pituitary hormone recipient's personal and clinical history, it will be reasonable to assume that the confirmed presence of such symptoms—if they become evident—could be attributed to CJD, and compensation processes will then be able to commence on considered expert medical advice.

The Commonwealth has already paid compensation to hormone recipients without autopsy. There are universally recognised signs of CJD which, on the balance of probabilities, can be attributable to CJD. The primary reason for the settlement proposal was to give `peace of mind' so that should someone contract CJD that person's dependants will also receive support.

In respect of the joint statement by Professors Mims and McCullagh on 22 April, this statement appears to be based upon a requirement that diagnosis and detection of a disease be "beyond reasonable doubt". This is not the test which the Commonwealth has used with respect to the Trust Account, the settlement of earlier claims following death or the settlement proposal currently being considered by recipients. As stated in the answer to question 6 (a) above, the Commonwealth uses the test that C]D is the most probable diagnosis rather than the more rigorous standard of "beyond reasonable doubt".
